blocks.html: Used by itself, 不得了 (bùdéliǎo) means "terrible" or "awful." But as a complement, -得不得了 (de bùdéliǎo) can be used to suggest a situation is serious or may result in terrible consequences. It can also be used in a positive sense, such as in English when we say "I'm terribly happy."

children.english: Dad is super angry. You're in for it.
Her mom just passed away, so she is extremely upset.
It's terribly cold today! How can it be this cold?
There are so many projects lately. We're crazy busy.
Getting promoted made him extremely happy.
He has a really good relationship with the big boss. You need to be careful!
He's terribly hot right now. Everyone knows him.
There are too many cars nowadays, so traffic is terrible.
Ever since she said she wanted to give me a gift I've been terribly curious.
I absolutely love these clothes.

blocks.html: As with many other grammar patterns, -得不得了 works with both adjectives and psychological verbs.
得不得了 vs. 不得不
blocks.text: 得不得了 vs. 不得不

blocks.html: A word to the wise: don't confuse 得不得了 (de bùdéliǎo) with 不得不 (bùdébù).

The complement -得很 (dehěn) is used after adjectives to add intensity. Although less common in everyday speech, meaning-wise it is quite similar to adding 很 before the adjective. The main difference is that "adjective + 得很" is more informal, and adds stronger emphasis than just "很 + adjective."

children.english: I'm doing great. You don't need to worry about me.
You don't think it tastes good? I think it's scrumptious.
This place is gorgeous. I strongly recommend you visit.
I have loads of free time right now. I can go with you wherever you want to go.
Don't worry. This test is super simple.
Stay away from me! I'm very stressed right now!
You think he's unhappy? From what I see, he's in a great mood today!
I've been so busy lately. I need to work overtime every day.
The traffic is really heavy at rush hour. I recommend you take the subway to work.
He's incredibly selfish. He never considers other people.

了一点儿 (le yīdiǎnr), can be added after an adjective to mean "just a little bit too...." It is softer in tone than using 太, and so is often used when the speaker doesn't want to insult the listener by criticizing too bluntly.

In this structure, the overall effect of the pattern depends on the preceding adjective. If the adjective in the structure has a negative meaning, then it is used to show the speaker’s dissatisfaction (a sort of complaint). If the adjective in the structure has a positive meaning, then it usually reflects a change.

children.english: This pair of jeans seems a little short for me.
That place is a little too far from my home.
This shirt is a little small. I want to exchange it for another one.
The amount of money he gave in the red envelope seems a bit small.
Don't you think you're getting a little too involved?
Isn't it a little too late to say sorry now?
Private schools are a little expensive, but the teachers are excellent.
You are so tall. Isn't your boyfriend a little short for you?
This dish is a little too salty, could you make another one?
This question is just a bit complicated for a five-year-old child.

blocks.html: 稍微 (shāowēi) can also be added before the adjective to further soften the tone.

In Chinese there is no shortage of ways to say "a lot." 有的是 (yǒudeshì) is one of those ways. However, we need to be very clear: 有的是 is not the same as 有的 (meaning "some") + 是. As a single phrase, 有的是 indicates that the amount or quantity of something is very large, and it can sometimes indicate a tone of exaggeration.
You can also put the noun at the beginning of the sentence, and put 有的是 at the end, like so:

children.english: His dad is a big boss. He's got plenty of money.
She's a full-time mother. She's got plenty of time.
I'm a big man. I've got plenty of strength.
Shanghai is such a big city. It's got plenty of job opportunities.
I have tons of this kind of pen at home. Here, just take these.
There's a lot of these kinds of resources on the Internet.
There are lots of this style of cafe in Shanghai.
Don't worry. There are plenty of men in the world. If you break up, you can find someone else.

blocks.html: It's important to note that "有的是" can not be directly negated. If you want to make a negative statement, you'll just have to use 没有很多.

children.english: I don't have a lot of money.

blocks.html: In its simplest terms, 都 (dōu) means "all," but there are also many other advanced uses for it.
都 Meaning "To the Point That"
都 can also mean 甚至 (shènzhì), meaning "even to the point that," and in this form it expresses emphasis.

children.english: I really miss Mom. Sometimes I can even see her.
I can even smell the aroma of bread.
I know you too well. I can even tell what your next move will be.
I can imagine all those things that you said.

blocks.html: This pattern overlaps a little with the 都……了 pattern used to mean "already." It still has some of that "already," flavor, but with some of "since" added in as well.
"Since ..., in that case...“ can also be conveyed with 都 and a repeating verb, similar to "既然⋯⋯就".

children.english: You're here already. No need to be in such a hurry to leave.
Go all the way, just have fun.

chineseWords.chars: 就别说这是什么秘密了

children.english: Say what you want to say, just don't spill secrets.

blocks.html: 都 Adding a Tone of Complaint
blocks.text: 都 Adding a Tone of Complaint

blocks.html: 都 can also convey a tone of grumbling or complaint, frequently used with 怨 or 怪. You might argue that this is simply the "all" adverb 都, and you wouldn't be wrong, but this usage is so common that it's worth special attention.

blocks.text: 都 + 怨 / 是 / 怪 + Somebody

children.english: It's all your fault, leaving without bringing an umbrella.
It's because of you, making me go all that way.
I blame you for not making the reservation earlier.

Aside from its other uses, 还 (hái) can be used to express a surprised or sarcastic tone, and can also be used with rhetorical questions.
Often used with 呢, this sentence structure expresses that the situation as irrational, uncommon, or unexpected.

children.english: This kid is brilliant!
He's even studied abroad, yet his English is so terrible!
It's all your fault, yet you're the one who's mad.

blocks.html: It can also be used to express astonishment, dissatisfaction, or sarcasm.

blocks.text: Subj. + 还 + Noun Phrase (+ 呢)

children.english: What a "good friend"! Talking trash about me every day.
Some "big boss," not generous in the least.
And you say my Chinese is good! Yet you're correcting me on every Chinese sentence I say...

blocks.html: Used in a Rhetorical Question
还 can change a statement into a rhetorical question when used with 吗.

children.english: He has so much money, would he really care about this small amount?
Would you believe this kind of person?
Would you drink expired milk?
It's so hot today, yet you're going out now?
Are you going to listen to what he says?

blocks.html: 总 (zǒng) can often be simply translated as "always," but it has other advanced uses as well. It can express "no matter how long or under what circumstances, facts are facts." It can also express "no matter what." It is often paired with other words to form set phrases such as 总会, 总归, 总得, 总要, 总能, etc. It can also be structured together with other unconditional compound phrases like 无论 and 不管. You cannot place it directly after the verb.

In this structure, 总, with its companion character (usually a modal/auxiliary verb), means "always will (fill in character/action here)" Once again, it gives the feeling of something very concrete and factual. As you'll see in the examples, below, however, the word "always" don't always work well in a natural translation to English.

blocks.text: 总 + 会 / 得 / 要 / 能 + Verb Phrase (+ 吧)

children.english: This is his home. He will always come back.
We're going to have to come up with some kind of solution.
No matter what happens, people still have to eat, right?
He is your father, so you ought to be a little more polite.
You took their money, so you're going to have to help them with the work.

blocks.text: Used with 不 and 没

blocks.html: When 总 is used together with a negating word (like 不 or 没), it often has a tone of speculation, judgment or suggestion. The sentence often ends with a 吧.

children.english: You talk to each other so little. It seems that you're barely family.
He's so elderly. We can't just let him go there all alone, right?
It's getting late. Do you think something bad might have happened?
This whole thing couldn't be an inside job, could it?
He wants to take his parents traveling, but he's never able to find time.

title: Assessing situations with "kanlai"
pattern: 看来 + Judgment to the Situation；在 + Person + 看来

blocks.html: 看来 (kànlái) can be translated as "apparently" or "it seems" and is used by the speaker to introduce his understanding of a situation.
Don't confuse 看来 with 看起来 (kànqilai), which means "it looks like."
When speaking objectively about a situation, you can simply say 看来 and then state your perspective.

children.english: It seems he's not coming. It's already so late.
It seems you didn't have a good time. Why did you came back so early?
It seems we are late. The line is so long.
It seems that the unemployment rate will increase this year because this year's economy is not very good.
Now it looks like things aren't that bad.

blocks.html: 看来 as "From X's Perspective"

看来 can also be used to highlight a specific person's point of view. This is like saying "the way he/she sees it..." You can also say 在我看来, which is the longer version of just using 看来. It is used more often that way in formal speaking and writing, as it has more of a feeling like saying, "in my opinion...."

children.english: The way I see it, people who won't spend money don't enjoy life.
In his view, the size of the company isn't important. What's important is whether or not the boss is good.
The way the boss sees it, only working overtime means you're proactive in your work.
According to friends, this situation is not very serious at all.
In your opinion, how can this issue be solved?

只好 (zhǐhǎo) is an adverb used to express that one "has no choice but to" or "has no other option but to." The option is one the speaker is not fond of.

children.english: The other restaurants are all closed, so we didn't have a choice but go to KFC to eat.
I forgot to make an appointment, so I had to wait in line.
He doesn't have time to go, so I have to go.
The boss wouldn't give me a raise, so I have to take on some side work.
She really couldn't stand such noisy neighbors, so she had to move away.
It suddenly rained that day, so we had to cancel it.
The police showed the surveillance to the thief, so he had to admit it.
The company can't afford the rent, so we have to work at home.
The fare was too expensive, so I gave up.
Work has been too busy lately, so I had no choice but to cancel my trip with my friend.

blocks.html: 可 (kě) can be used to intensify an adjective, or to add emphasis to a verb. It is stronger than other modifiers, as 可 compares the speaker‘s expectations with the actual situation. The meaning of 可 is very reliant on context.
可 is generally used by Northern speakers and is informal, generally only used in spoken Chinese.
可 Used to Intensify an Adjective
blocks.text: 可 Used to Intensify an Adjective

blocks.html: The 了 is almost always there, but it's not 100%.
In these examples, 可 is used a bit like 很, as it is used to intensify an adjective:

children.explanation: The speaker never expected puppies to be this naughty
children.english: This puppy is so naughty!
My sister is great! Any good food there is she saves some for me.
He is really excellent! Don't you want to meet him?
This game is really fun! I recommend it to you.

children.explanation: The speaker never dreamt that sweet and sour pork could taste this good
children.english: Wow! This sweet and sour pork is delicious!

blocks.html: 可 Used to Emphasize a Verb
blocks.text: 可 Used to Emphasize a Verb

blocks.html: 了 is not needed in this pattern, but may be present.
In these examples 可 is used with 别, and sounds a bit like "don't even think about..." in English.

children.explanation: I know you usually drink a lot, but NOT THIS TIME
children.english: Don't drink too much.

children.explanation: I'm blocking your way, almost pleading with you, as I believe you are going to leave
children.english: Don't go!

children.explanation: What you said doesn't accord with my own beliefs
children.english: You really can't say that.

blocks.html: Sometimes 可 acts like 终于 (zhōngyú), meaning "finally."
了 will pretty much always be needed when you're talking about something "finally" happening.

children.explanation: The speaker never expected it would take so long for you to get here
children.english: You're finally here!
I've finally finished all the work.

毕竟 (bìjìng) can be used to emphasize a reason or characteristic, and is like "after all" where you might say, "he is, after all, only a child." 毕竟 is used both in spoken and written Chinese.
In its most basic form, you just need to add the "after all" stuff after the 毕竟, and it could be a reason or a characteristic.

children.english: Stop yelling at him. He's only a kid, after all.
It's winter, after all. You'd better dress more warmly.
It's not strange that he doesn't know. He's not a local, after all.
Some things shouldn't be joked about anymore. After all, they're not little kids anymore.
We don't really want to move. After all, we've lived here for so many years.

blocks.text: 虽然 ⋯⋯ ，但 + 毕竟 ⋯⋯ ，(as a result) ⋯⋯

blocks.html: In this structure, the parts after 虽然 (suīrán) and 毕竟 are reasons or characteristics, and the part after (as a result) is a result or conclusion. It's a bit more complex, so pay attention to the different parts in the example sentences below.

children.english: Although he made a mistake, he is, after all, still young. So stop hitting him.
Although I'm dressed really warmly, it is, after all, winter in the north. I still feel quite cold.
Although I know him, we're not close, after all. We'd better not bother him.
Although my grandma didn't treat me well when I was little, she is my grandma, after all, so I will still take care of her.
Although you are divorced, you still have a child together, after all. So don't fight when you're with the child.

title: Expressing a last chance with "zaibu... jiu..."

blocks.html: When time is running out and you need to emphasize that someone needs to act now or else something bad is going to happen, that's when you know you need the pattern 再不…… 就…… (zàibù... jiù...)!
What comes right after 再不 is the action that needs to be taken now. What comes after 就 is the dire consequences which will immediately result is that action is not taken.

Technically this pattern is just a combination of the "again" in the future 再 and the 就 for expressing "then". But somehow this pattern does not easily come to mind for most learners when you want to express "if you don't... now.... then..." so it gets its own grammar point.
Note that there is a sense of urgency in each of these sentences, even if the word 现在 isn't present. That's why an implied "now" has been added in for some English translations.

children.english: If you don't leave now, I'm going to call security.
If we don't leave now, we will be late for our meeting.
If you don't start working hard, you're going to get eliminated.
The train is about to leave! If we don't get our tickets checked now, we're not going to make it.
It's the final sale of the year. If you don't grab it, it'll be gone!
Hurry up and tell him; don't let him get the wrong idea. If you don't tell him now he's really going to get the wrong message.
If you don't study, you won't have an allowance to live on next month.
If you don't call now, you're going to miss out on this opportunity.
If we don't travel now, we won't have the opportunity in the future.
If I don't wear a down jacket, I'm going to freeze to death.

Logically, 差点没 (chàdiǎn méi) is just a simple extension of 差点, adding the negation after it. In fact, you shouldn't think of it as a single word; think of the 没 as belonging to what follows 差点 and it makes more sense. Still, it can be a little confusing for many learners, and is worth a closer look.
Obviously, 差点 and 差点儿 are equivalent here.

blocks.text: Subj. + 差点 + 没 + Verb Phrase

blocks.html: Note that the "Verb Phrase" part is a desired result. So this structure is literally saying, "almost didn't [Verb Phrase]."
Also note that because you're using 没, you don't use 了 after the verb phrase.

children.explanation: I did recall it.
children.english: I almost couldn't recall it.

children.explanation: I almost missed it, but I didn't.
children.english: I almost missed the train.

children.explanation: He did pass it, but almost didn't.
children.english: He barely passed the examination.
I almost didn't get the visa.

children.explanation: I did get it.
children.english: The waiting line is too long. I almost didn't get it.
The two of them almost didn't pass the interview.

blocks.html: This is the weird one. In the following usages, 差点 and 差点没 are equivalent. It's almost as if the 没 is meaningless. You can literally drop it with no change in meaning, but only when there is an undesired result after 差点没.

blocks.text: Subj. + 差点 (+ 没) + Verb Phrase

blocks.html: In this pattern, the "Verb Phrase" part is an undesired result. So in terms of meaning, this structure is identical to the regular 差点 structure.
Again, because you're using 没 here, you don't use 了 after the verb phrase.

children.english: I almost ran into her.
This place is so big. I walked for so long I almost died from exhaustion.
I was almost discovered.
This place has almost become a dump.

Lovers of the word "anyways" in English, rejoice! The word 反正 (fǎnzhèng) works essemtially the same way. It means "anyhow," or "regardless," and is used to disregard a previous statement, particularly those involving options or choices.
反正 as "No Matter What"
You can put 反正 in the sentence after a comma or pause, similar to how we use "anyway" in English. It can be used with "不管."

children.english: Regardless of whether he's going or not, I'm going anyway.
No matter whether you believe this or not, I believe it anyway.
No matter who his father is, I'm going to sue him anyway.
Other people can think whatever they want. I don't really care what people think.
Whether I speak or not, it's all the same. Nobody is going to listen to me anyway.

blocks.html: 反正 to Emphasize a Reason
blocks.text: 反正 to Emphasize a Reason

blocks.html: 反正, in this case, is used to convey a certainty or resolution. It‘s similar to 既然 (jìrán). 反正 goes at the beginning of the clause introducing the reason, but that clause can come first or second in the sentence. (既然 is not quite so flexible.)

children.english: They are not coming anyway, so let's just go by ourselves.
I'll just give it to you. I don't need it anyway.
My house is big enough, you can all stay here tonight.
What are you still afraid of? Everybody knows about it now anyway.
Anyway, we can just use a credit card. It’s no big deal to have no cash.

尽量 (jǐnliàng) is an adverb meaning "as much as possible" or "to the greatest extent." In this article, we will do our best to explain how to use it!
Using 尽量 is as simple as adding it before a verb (or adjective).

children.english: I will try my best to figure out something to help you.
I'll do my best to tell you everything I know.
Go ahead and study, I'll do my best to not disturb you.
You are the big brother and you should try your best to look after your little sister.
Parents should spend as much time as possible with their children.
We should avoid asking this kind of questions, which could make some clients very uncomfortable.
I will do my best to complete the project by this Sunday.
We have to try our best to meet the client's needs.
The boss is angry. Be as tactful as possible with him.
The budget for this project is very tight, so we have to control the cost and try not to exceed the budget.

blocks.html: You may hear the word 尽量 pronounced as both "jǐnliàng" and "jìnliàng." Although "jǐnliàng" is technically correct and "jìnliàng" is supposed to be a verb (not an adverb like the word above), many educated native speakers will pronounce 尽量 exclusively as "jìnliàng."

恐怕 (kǒngpà) can be used to express "I'm afraid that," or "I'm concerned that," or even "I'm worried that," followed by some sort of reason. It doesn't need to be something you're literally afraid of; it may be that you're just trying to soften the blow of some bad news, as in, "I'm afraid that I'm too busy washing my hair tomorrow night to come over and see the 2000 pictures of your trip to ComicCon."
恐怕 comes at the beginning of the sentence. It's often used with auxiliary verbs such as 要, 会, 能, 得, etc.
Note that it sounds better to put 恐怕 before the subject of the sentence.

children.english: I'm afraid it's going to rain today.
I'm afraid we're going to need your help with this matter.
I'm afraid it's not appropriate to do this.
This is an important decision. I'm afraid you can't rush this one.
Dear, I'm going to work late tonight. I'm afraid I can't go home to eat dinner.
This pink is too much. I'm afraid my daughter isn't going to like it.
You finally realized that you were ripped off? I'm afraid the scammer is long gone.

blocks.html: 恐怕 is also often used in conjunction with 吧. When it is used with 吧, it expresses a soft but concerned tone and is typically used when the speaker wishes to give their advice or opinion on a matter.

children.english: I'm afraid it's not that easy.
I'm afraid it's not safe to go there alone.
If you put it that way, I'm afraid she will be upset.

好不容易 (hǎo bù róngyì) means "very difficult" or "really not easy." It is often used where the speaker wants to comment on the result of their hard work, something like "It was really hard for me to x, but then I realized y."
Sentences using 好不容易 are often followed by 才 (cái), emphasizing the action has been completed only with great difficulty.
Strange as it might seem, 好容易 has the same meaning as 好不容易, and can be used interchangeably. 好不容易 is more common.

blocks.text: Subj. + 好 (不) 容易 + 才 + [Result]

blocks.html: The "result" part can be a simple phrase or a whole clause.

children.english: She had a hard time losing weight and succeeded..
It was no easy task to get through to the bank's customer service hotline.
It was with great difficulty that we finally finished this project. But then the contract was canceled.
It was a lot of trouble to get to the city center, but then I realized I had forgotten my cell phone and had to go back and get it.
After the financial crisis, he had a hard time finally finding a job. And now he's resigning.
With great difficulty, they finally climbed to the top of the mountain. And then it started raining heavily.
The teacher had a difficult time making the students correct the wrong sentences.

blocks.text: Verb / [Verb Phrase] + 好容易 / 好不容易

blocks.html: In this simpler structure we use 好(不)容易 by itself to express “with great difficulty”. At the end of the sentence particles such as 啊 or 哦 will also often be used to add emotion.

children.english: Finishing this big project will not be an easy task.
Raising a child is not an easy thing to do.
Starting a company isn't easy.

blocks.html: 甚至 (shènzhì) is similar to "even" in English and is used for emphasis. Like "even," it can be used quite directly or in a more subtle manner. When used more subtly it acts to supplement the speaker’s initial thought, creating the impression that the speaker has realized half way through his statement that he hasn’t gone far enough, and wants to take the idea one step further.
甚至 Used to Emphasize a Noun
blocks.text: 甚至 Used to Emphasize a Noun

blocks.html: Note the word or phrase following 甚至 often uses 也 or 都 to add further emphasis. The noun being emphasized is the "surprising" one or one that is the most "extreme."

blocks.text: [Noun or Group of Nouns] + 甚至 + [Emphasized Noun] + 都 / 也 ⋯⋯

children.english: Each and every member of the audience, and even the referee, stood up and applauded for him.
I've been to many cities in China: Beijing, Shanghai, Hangzhou, Kunming, Guilin. I even went to Lhasa once.
None of my friends like my decision, and even my family doesn't support it.
He likes playing on his cell phone when he's eating, taking the metro, even when he goes to the bathroom.

blocks.html: 甚至 in Complex Sentences
Note the sentence following 甚至 often uses 也 or 都 to add further emphasis, and 连 (lián) sometimes directly follows 甚至 for further "even" emphasis.

children.english: He's too busy. He doesn't even have time to eat lunch.
He never talks about work, not even to his wife.
This question is simple, even kids know the answer.
My boyfriend likes swimming a lot. He goes swimming even when it's winter.
I haven't seen him for a few years and he's gotten much fatter. I, as an old friend, couldn't even recognize him.

尽管 (jǐnguǎn) is an adverb which means "feel free to," and can be used to encourage someone to not be shy about doing something.

children.english: Feel free to speak up if you have anything to say.
Feel free to ask if you have any questions.
Feel free to ask me for help if you need anything.
Feel free to help yourself to these drinks. They are all free of charge.
Feel free to order anything you like. My treat.
Feel free to just do it. Don't worry about the result.
Feel free to offer any opinion. I won't get angry.
Feel free to buy whatever you want,I can afford a few pieces of clothing.
Feel free to go wherever you want. Travel is really convenient right now.
Feel free to say what you want. Mom will meet your demands.

blocks.html: You may hear the word 尽管 pronounced as both "jǐnguǎn" and "jìnguǎn." Although "jǐnguǎn" is technically correct and "jìnguǎn" is incorrect, many educated native speakers will pronounce 尽量 exclusively as "jìnguǎn."
不得不 (bùdébù) has a stronger tone than 必须 (bìxū) meaning "someone cannot help but do something."

children.english: You are so good. I have to admit it.
I must study hard for the future.
The elevator is broken again. We have to take the stairs.
You are quite the smooth talker. We can't help but admire that about you.
I'm sorry, but time is very limited. I have to interrupt you.
It's an emergency situation. We must come up with something fast.
Because he was sick, he had no choice but to give up this trip.
My leg was injured, so I had no choice but to drop out of the competition.
In order to buy a new phone, Xiao Ming had to get a part time job.
We all employees here. We have to follow what the company has decided.

blocks.html: 到底 (dàodǐ) literally means "to the bottom," and often is used where the speaker wants to get to the bottom of a problem or issue, emphasizing or questioning what the real reason for something is.
到底 as 毕竟 or "In the End"
blocks.text: 到底 as 毕竟 or "In the End"

blocks.html: It is often used like 毕竟, to mean "after all" or "in the end." When used in this way, 到底 is used to emphasize a reason or characteristic the speaker considers to be most important.

children.english: Look how generous he is with money. He is a high-level boss, after all....
"He is a master, after all. Look how quickly he solved the problem.
"He is a kid, after all. It's normal for him to not understand some things.

blocks.html: 到底 as 究竟 or "On Earth"
blocks.text: 到底 as 究竟 or "On Earth"

blocks.html: 到底 can be used to mean "on earth" (as in "what on earth?!") where it is used to add emphasis or urgency to a question. In this sense, 到底 is similar to 究竟.

blocks.text: 到底 + Verb ＋ 不 / 没 ＋ Verb

children.english: What on earth is up with you?
How on earth do we get there?
Speak up! Who on earth is your boyfriend?
Are you going to tell me or not?
Do you like me or not?
Did they get divorced or not?

blocks.html: Note that 到底 can't appear in an answer to a question. Also, 吗 can't appear in a question formed with 到底 but 没有 can be used instead:

children.english: Have you eaten or not?

blocks.html: 到底 as 终于 or "Finally"
blocks.text: 到底 as 终于 or "Finally"

blocks.html: 到底 can be used to mean "finally." In this sense, 到底 is similar to 终于.

children.english: The weather is finally warm.
He finally understood.
After working on it for over two years, our project finally succeeded.

When someone asks you "what on earth are you doing?," "究竟 (jiūjìng)" is used by the speaker to intensify the question. In this case, 究竟 is similar to 到底, but a bit more formal.
Using 究竟 in Questions
Using 究竟 in Targeted Questions
blocks.text: Using 究竟 in Targeted Questions

blocks.html: These questions are aimed at finding out a specific piece of info, such as a name or time.

children.english: Who on earth is this guy?
What exactly is it that you do?
When exactly are they arriving?
How much longer do we still need to wait?
What on earth do you want me to do?

blocks.html: Using 究竟 in Yes/No Questions
blocks.text: Using 究竟 in Yes/No Questions
究竟 ＋ Verb ＋ 没 / 不 ＋ Verb

children.english: Are you coming or not?
Can you guys help me or not?
So, is she your girlfriend or not?
So, do you like me or not?
Did the manager agree or not?

blocks.html: Using 究竟 in Affirmative Sentences
blocks.text: Using 究竟 in Affirmative Sentences

blocks.html: 究竟 can also be used with 是 for an emphasis of a fact, which is similar to 毕竟, meaning "after all."

children.english: Kids are kids after all, always thinking about how to have fun.
Shanghai is Shanghai after all. The living expenses here are just high.
Young people are young, after all. They are so full of energy.
Businessmen are businessmen, after all. The most important thing to them is making money.
Family is family, after all. You may not like them, but you still love them.

Since you can't learn it, just stop studying.
This crappy old computer broke again. Might as well not fix it and just buy a new one.
Apples are too expensive. I didn't buy them, and just bought some bananas.
This person is not honest. Just don't be friends with him.
It's no fun here. Let's just go home.
Since you like this sofa too, let's just buy it and take it home.
I'll just listen to you. I haven't made any sort of plan anyway.

几乎 (jīhū) means "nearly" or "almost," and is used to emphasize that someone or something is very close to doing something.
几乎 is often used together with words that mean "all," such as 每, 所有, or 全. It can also be used with words that mean "none" such as 没有.

blocks.text: 几乎 + 没有 + Noun Phrase ……

children.english: Almost everyone has a cell phone.
In our company, almost everyone can speak English.
In China, almost all foreigners can say "nihao."
Almost no one believes him.
Almost all viewers the world over like this movie.

blocks.text: Subj. + 几乎 + [不 / 没 +] Predicate

children.english: Dad's hair is almost all white.
They spent almost all of their money on this trip.
He ate almost the whole cake by himself.
My boss rarely drinks.
Boss has barely taken a decent break these past few months.

title: Expressing "never again" with "zai ye bu"
pattern: Subj. + 再也 + 不 + Verb Phrase + 了

blocks.html: Sometimes you may do something or experience something that you never ever want to do again. How do we express that in Chinese? One of the ways is to use this quirky combination of three little words: 再也不 (zài yě bù)!
Using 再也 with 不
To express that something will never be done again, or never happen again, you can use this structure:

blocks.text: Subj. + 再也 + 不 (+ Auxiliary Verb) + Verb Phrase + 了

blocks.html: Notice that 了 is used. In this case it's "change of state 了". This is because it is now the case that the action will not be done again. It indicates some kind of determination or decision.

children.english: I never want to see you again!
I don't want to talk with you ever again.
We're not going to believe you ever again!
The doctor said she will never be able to dance again.
I'm not going to leave you ever again.

blocks.html: Using 再也 with 没

blocks.text: Subj. + 再也 + 没 + Verb + 过 + Obj.

blocks.html: Notice that 过 is used. This pattern expresses that during a certain period of time in the past, or from a certain point in the past up until now, something hasn't been done again.

children.english: Since then, I've never been to a bar again.
Since leaving my country, I've never eaten any authentic Chinese food.
They haven't seen each other ever since they broke up.
She has never spent her parents' money since she graduated.
Since finishing exams I haven't touched those books again.

title: Expressing "once" with "cengjing"
pattern: Subj. + 曾经 + Verb + 过 (+ Obj.)

blocks.html: 曾经 (céngjīng) is an adverb, and as such comes before verb phrases in a sentence. It adds the sense of "once" having happened (the "once upon a time" meaning of "once"), sometimes translated as "ever." It frequently pairs with 过.
Used with 过
When used with action verbs, 曾经 comes before the verb, which is then followed by 过. For psychological verbs, the 过 is optional.

blocks.text: Subj. + 曾经 + Verb + 过 (+ Obj.)

children.english: We once went there together.
He said that he once did a lot of stupid things.
I once liked you.
She once wanted to become an actress. She later became a stay-at-home mom.

blocks.html: Sometimes 曾经 is used with 了 rather than 过.

children.english: In order to find her biological parents, she once spent a lot of money.

blocks.html: 曾经 can also be used with some adjectives. In these cases, 过 is usually also used.

children.english: We were all young once.
His music was once popular.

blocks.html: Used without 过
When used with the verbs 是, 在, and 有 (all related to existence rather than actions), 过 is generally not used.

blocks.text: 曾经 + 是 / 在 / 有 ⋯⋯

children.english: He was once my boss.
There was once a school here.
The municipal government [building] was once next to our house.
His tomb was once overseas.
She once had a Spanish boyfriend.
Their family once had lots of money.

blocks.html: Because 过 is used to talk about past actions, it should be negated with 没 (méi). When you mean to say "I haven't ever (done something)" or "(something) hasn't happened ever," just say 没⋯⋯过. It is incorrect to use 没 or 不 to negate 曾经.

children.english: We've never argued.
They've been writing letters to each other, but they've never met.

blocks.html: 不曾 (bùcéng) and 未曾 (wèicéng), however, can also be used to express the above meaning, but they're more formal and thus used only in written language.

blocks.text: 不曾 / 未曾 + Verb + 过 + Obj.

children.english: They've been writing letters to each other, but they've never met.
He's had no parents since he was very young. He's never experienced the warmth of a family.

There are a number of ways to express "originally" in Chinese, and 本来 (běnlái) is one of the ones first learned, partly because its two characters are so simple.
Using 本来是 (běnlái shì) for a Change of Plans
blocks.text: Using 本来是 (běnlái shì) for a Change of Plans

blocks.html: 本来 means "originally." Use it when you need to explain that happened unexpectedly later. Since the action has already happened, the 是... 的 construction is likely appropriate here. 是 is optional.

blocks.text: Subj. + 本来 + 是 +（不）[要 / 会 / 应该] + Verb + 的，[但是 / 可是 / 不过]...

children.english: I originally wanted to go, but I didn't go because I didn't feel very well.
This work was originally supposed to be done by today, but it's OK to do it tomorrow.
I was originally going to marry him, but then I found that we are really not right for each other.
He would have done better on the test, but he was sick that day.
We were going to go ask him for help, but we didn't because he is so busy.

blocks.html: Using 本来就 (běnlái jiù) for Emphasis of a Viewpoint
blocks.text: Using 本来就 (běnlái jiù) for Emphasis of a Viewpoint

blocks.html: If you've got an opinion to express after stating how it "should be" or "should not be," then 本来就 will help you sound more convincing. The end of the sentence usually has an imperative or rhetorical question that leads to an opinion or suggestion, emphasizing the tone.

children.english: You are already so thin and you still want to lose weight?
What he says has always been wrong, so why do you still want me to listen to him?
She is rich. Of course she can afford it.
She never liked you in the first place, so stop pursuing her.
He has always liked joking around, so don't take it personally.

blocks.html: 本来 (běnlái) with 就 (jiù) to Express "Duh!"
blocks.text: 本来 (běnlái) with 就 (jiù) to Express "Duh!"

blocks.html: 本来 (běnlái) is used to stress that the speaker believes something to be common knowledge. "Duh" is probably an overly saracastic and informal English equivalent, so another translation could be "it goes without saying." It's often easier to translate the feeling imparted by 本来就 as "supposed to," following it with a certain expectation.

blocks.text: Subj. + 本来 + 就 + 很 / 不 + Adj.
Subj. + 本来 + 就 + 会 / 要 / 得 / 应该 + Verb

children.english: Taking care of children is supposed to be the responsibility of parents.
Teachers are supposed to prepare their lessons well.

children.explanation: Literally, "Moving is supposed to be troublesome."
children.english: Moving is always a pain.

children.explanation: Literally, "Life was never supposed to be easy."
children.english: No one ever said life was easy.

简直 (jiǎnzhí) is similar to "simply" or "completely" in English, and can be used to modify adjectives or verbs, adding a tone of amazement on the part of the speaker.

children.english: This place is simply heaven.
His singing is simply awful!
Your boyfriend is simply gorgeous!
I just don't understand why he's so stupid.
I just don't know how I am supposed to teach such kinds of students.
The cake mom made is delicious, compared to the cake you can buy in stores it is still better.
I heard this news and it was like eating a super sweet piece of candy.

blocks.html: However, although it is possible in English to  say something is "simply beautiful," in Chinese, 简直 cannot be followed directly by an unmodified adjective. 很 is also not used after 简直. Check out the following examples:

children.english: She is simply too pretty!
She is just so pretty!

blocks.html: When followed immediately by 是, the word 简直 takes on a meaning similar to "basically."

children.english: He's just lying to you.
You are simply too nosy.
This puppy is just too cute, the more you look at him the more you like him.
They are basically stealing our creativity.
What you are doing is basically destroying the atmosphere.
He is a badminton champion, and playing badminton against you is simply too easy.
I didn't eat meat for a month just to challenge myself.

一向 (yīxiàng) means "always," but is generally used to express a habit, attitude, or convention which has continued for a long period of time until the present. When you use 一向, you're conveying a sense that "it's always been this way."

blocks.text: Subj. + 一向 + Habit / Attitude / etc.

children.english: Xiao Wang has always started work very early. What happened this time?
I have never liked ordering takeout.
Mom has always supported my decisions.
He's always been a good student, why would he possibly cheat?
Chinese people have always considered red to be a lucky and joyous color.
Yunnan's rainy season always comes suddenly.
His attitude has always been very serious.
I always do it like this. It's no problem.

blocks.html: 一向 cannot be used with verbs involving changes or actions. In this case, 一直 should be used:

children.explanation: It must have started developing at some point.

children.english: China's economy has been continuously developing rapidly.

children.explanation: He must have started, right?

children.english: He's been studying Mandarin all this time.

blocks.html: 一向 indicates that a certain state has continued until the present. It cannot be used to express actions in the future. Again, 一直 can be used instead:

children.english: Do you plan to work in Shanghai indefinitely?

千万 (qiānwàn) looks like a number ("thousand ten thousand"?) but it actually means "to make certain." It is more common in the negative form, but is also used in the positive. It really adds a kick to your sentence!

千万 usually starts the imperative sentence or phrase, and it is usually paired with 要, 不能, 别 or similar types of words. You can use 千万 with sentences that are commanding someone not do do something, or you can tell them to do something.
The following examples use 千万 in the negative to strongly command someone not to do something.

children.english: This dish is horrible. Make sure you don't order it!
It's too dangerous there. Whatever you do, don't go!
Their products are fake. DO NOT buy them!
He is not a good person, you really can't believe him!
When a child does wrong, parents can teach them. But they really mustn't beat them!

blocks.html: 千万 with "Do"
The following examples use 千万 to strongly command someone to do something.

children.english: When crossing the street, you really must careful!
You must memorize this phrase by heart!
When traveling alone, you really must pay attention to safety!
Before leaving make absolute sure to lock the door!
The rain makes the road slick. You really must drive slowly!

白 (bái) doesn't only mean "white." When added before a verb it means to do that verb "in vain" or "with no effect."
Basic Form with Just 白
All you have to do is put 白 before the verb. One important thing to note is that 白 is usually used with mono-syllabic words, like 做, 学, 跑, etc. You should put a 地 after 白.

children.english: I just wasted a hundred kuai. I can't even wear these clothes.
He's not coming back to eat?! I made all this food for nothing.
You can't speak even one sentence in Chinese! All that time studying was a waste.
He wasn't home when I got there, so I wasted all of that time going over there.
Sorry to make you work this whole morning for nothing. Our boss just said that he couldn't come today.

blocks.html: Form with 白白

白 can also be replaced with 白白 with basically the same meaning, although 白白 has a stronger emphasis on the "wasted effort." 白白 is also usually paired with a disyllabic verb, like 帮助, 准备, 学习 etc. Unlike 白, 白白 can be used with a 地.

children.english: There's no Chinese test tomorrow. Little Wang spent the whole day studying in vain.
He still doesn't listen to my advice. I spent such a long time talking to him, all for nothing.
He didn't come. I wasted four hours at the airport waiting for him.
Your parents raised you for so many years, just for you not to care about them at all.
She spent ten years fruitlessly studying English. She can read English, but she can't even hold a simple conversation!

blocks.html: There are a group of mono-syllabic verbs that combine with 白 in the same structure, but for these verbs, 白 means "for free." Think of these as set phrases. All relate to the senses or some form of "consumption." This list is not exhaustive:

children.english: to eat for free
to drink for free
to stay (overnight) for free

Although sometimes translated as "in passing" or even "conveniently," the most common way that the idea of adverb 顺便 (shùnbiàn) is expressed in English is "while you're at it" (or "while I'm at it," etc.). It's the idea of doing something at a convenient and logical time to save effort. Now you just have to get used to expressing this concept as an adverb.
General Usage of 顺便

blocks.text: Subj. + Verb Phrase 1, 顺便 + Verb Phrase 2

children.english: When you go out to get breakfast can you also bring me a cup of coffee?
Could you pick me up a bottle of milk while you're at the supermarket?
The boss went to see the client and also ate lunch while he was at it.
I'm going to Beijing on a business trip next week. I'll go to visit a friend while I'm there.
I take the trash out as I leave the house.
Ask him if he's coming this weekend when you see him.

blocks.html: Colloquial Usage of 顺便
Here 顺便 means something like "by the way, I'd like to...."

children.english: By the way, I moved recently.
By the way, when next week are you coming back?
By the way, the computer's been fixed.
By the way, I just wanted to ask you: what do you think of Xiao Wang?

title: Repeated actions in the past with "you"
pattern: Subj. + Verb + 了 + 又 + Verb

blocks.html: To emphasize that an action is being repeated again and again, we can place 又 after a verb, then repeat the same verb again.

In the pattern below, 又, together with a repeating verb, indicates that the speaker did something repeatedly (and probably not just twice) in the past. Note that the verb used here must be a single-syllable verb, usually a verb such as 看, 想, 问, 找, or 试. 了 is placed right after the first verb.

blocks.text: Subj. ＋ Verb + 了 + 又 + Verb， (还是 / 就是) ……

blocks.html: Note that "还是" or "就是" is often used to emphasize that "nothing changed" after all.

children.english: I looked at him again and again, but I still think I don't know him.
I thought it over again and again, but I still feel I can't do this.
He searched again and again, and still couldn't find his wallet.
He thought it over again and again, and he still disagrees.
We asked again and again, but she wouldn't tell us.
He tried again and again, but he still couldn't open the door.
I tasted it again and again, but I still think the food has gone bad.
He sniffed again and again, but he still didn't smell anything.
This plan was changed again and again, and finally it was approved.
Mother washed this clothing again and again, and it's finally clean.

Rhetorical questions use the form of a question to emphasize a point, thus do not require an answer. A typical English rhetorical question might be: "you're not saying you actually believe him, are you?" or "just how stupid are you?" In Chinese, 难道 (nándào) is used as a marker to form this kind of question. Since we don't "mark" our rhetorical questions like this in English, this can take some getting used to in Chinese.

children.english: You don't actually believe him, do you?
What are you, my mother or something?
Today's my birthday; you're telling me you didn't know?
Did you not go to work today?
You are so calm. Do you not know what happened?
Your parents care so much about you. Don't tell me that you don't feel it at all?
He's so handsome and rich! Are you telling me that you don't want to marry him?

blocks.html: Note that 难道 can only be used for rhetorical questions which could be answered with yes or no, and generally end with 吗.

children.english: How much money should I give you?

children.explanation: Not a 吗 question
children.english: How long do they still have to wait?
How many more years do you want to work for this kind of  company?

blocks.html: You might be used to thinking of 差不多 (chàbuduō) as a single word, and that's totally OK. But if you want to negate the whole idea of rough equivalency, then you need to think of it as a phrase and use 差很多 (chà hěn duō). Not surprisingly, it's a little less versatile than 差不多.

When 差不多 (chàbuduō) is a predicate, it literally means "the difference is not much." The opposite, then, would be 差很多 (chà hěn duō), which literally means "the difference is very great." Less literally, if 差不多 means "more or less the same," then 差很多 means "not the same at all" or "very different."

blocks.text: A + 跟 / 和 + B + 差很多

children.english: Chinese culture and western culture are quite different.
The meanings of these two words are basically the same, but their usages are very different.
There is a big difference between her age and her husband's age.
The company's income for this year is quite different from last year.
There is a big difference in the attitude between this waiter and his manager.
My life habits are very different from my parents'.
They are both great teachers, but their educational backgrounds are very different.
There are huge differences in the features between the old version and the new one.
These two pieces of clothing look pretty much the same, but their quality is very different.
They are twins, but their personalities are very different.

When listing nouns belonging to a certain category, 啊 (a) can be added to the end of each noun to give an informal feeling a bit like saying "you know, that kind of thing" after a list of things. You're giving the sense that you're not listing every single thing that you could; it's a non-exhaustive list.

blocks.text: A 啊， B 啊， C 啊 (+ 什么的)⋯⋯

blocks.html: The list can be followed by 什么的, but is not generally followed by 等等 as this feels too formal.

children.english: We have all sorts of snacks: peanuts, roasted seeds, chips, go ahead and eat whatever you want.
Xiao Wang, Xiao Li, and Xiao Zhang all work for the same company, you can ask them.
Cell phones have many features like taking photos, watching videos, and listening to music. They can do it all.
Chairs, tables, computers, and so on have all been bought. Now the office only needs to hire staff!
Spring Festival, Mid-Autumn Festival, Dragon Boat Festival, are all important Chinese holidays.
This song is too popular! On the street, in the car, on TV, they are all playing this song.
"Integrated Chinese," "Developing Chinese," and "The Practical Chinese Reader"... I've studied them all!
Going to Shanghai, Hangzhou, Nanjing, are all very convenient.

blocks.html: 于是 is a conjunction used to express a continuation between two events. The second event is the direct result of the first event. You'll often hear 于是 used in storytelling.
于是 is a conjunction that comes between two clauses. Its closest English equivalent would be "and then." Since 于是 can only be used to talk about the past, 了 is often used in the same sentence.

children.english: I saw everyone was buying it. So then I bought it, too.
It rained yesterday, so we cancelled the picnic.
The tickets on the website were all sold out. So then we bought tickets from scalpers.
His English was too terrible. So then his mother hired an English tutor for him.
She found out that her boyfriend was already married. So she immediately broke up with him.

blocks.html: 于是 Used with 就
于是 is often used with 就 to emphasize that the actions or events that come after 就 are immediately after the first event.

children.english: This movie was so violent, we couldn't bear watching it anymore. So then we left.
He was way too lazy, so the boss just let him go.
I really like this cell phone, so I just bought it.
That student didn't study seriously, so he was scolded by his mother.
While chatting they had just gotten to the topic of travel, and then the two of them really got going, talking non-stop.

blocks.html: 因此 vs. 于是

While they may seem very similar, 因此 is not quite the same as 于是. When using 因此, it acts as a conjunction that expresses the cause and effect. Because of the reasons in clause one, clause two reaches this result or conclusion.
• 因此 emphasizes a cause and effect relationship. 于是 emphasizes that the first event is closely followed by the second event.
• 于是 can only be used to recount events that happened in the past.
• 因此 is more formal and mostly used in writing. 于是 is more commonly used when speaking.

children.english: He often makes jokes recklessly. Therefore, people doesn't like to talk to him.

blocks.html: In the incorrect sentence above, it is not two sequential events that happened in the past, so 于是 is not appropriate. In the correct sentence, there is a clear cause-effect relationship, so 因此 is used.

The conjunction 而 (ér) is used to connect two sentences that are related to each other, and is also frequently used to emphasize contrast between two parts of the sentence. Used in this way, it can be translated as "but rather." 而 is often used in more formal or literary language, but is also common in everyday speech.
Start with 是
Frequently you'll see the pattern in one of these two more specific forms involving the verb 是:
Strictly speaking, the 而 isn't required in either of these patterns, but it makes the contrast super clear.

children.english: We're here to do work, not to have fun.
The person to later regret this won't be me. It will be you.
By doing this you were hurting him, not helping him.
I'm sorry. It was an accident. It wasn't on purpose.
Now is not the time to place blame, but rather to figure out how to resolve this.
I didn't tell you not because I wanted to deceive you, but rather I was afraid you would be upset.
It's not that I don't want to help you, it's that I have no way to help you.
What's important is not how you look on the outside, but rather what's on the inside.
It's not that life is lacking in beauty, but rather that we lack eyes that discover it.
I went to your home today looking for you, but you weren't there.
Your child has a very severe fever, and yet you don't seem at all concerned.
She is very popular in our company, but I don't like her at all.

blocks.html: As you can see, 而 comes between the two to stress the contrast.

blocks.html: 当中 (dāngzhōng) means "among," or more literally "in the middle of." In English this is a bit like "of," as in, "of all of my friends, you are the most loyal." Also, 当中 can be used to express being "in the middle" of an activity or process that is fairly formal in nature, such as "in the middle of negotiations."

children.english: Of all of my friends, you are the smartest one.
Among these one hundred contestants, my performance was the most outstanding.
Among them, there are many Shanghainese.
Of the five people, one of them is a thief.
Of the many restaurants, theirs is best.
This engineering project is still in the planning stage.
This batch of products is still being designed and has not been finalized.
We are still in the process of considering it, please don't get impatient.
It still under investigation, so the result is not yet known.
I'm in the process of moving, and every day I have many things to deal with.

blocks.html: When used to express "among," 当中 is a little like 其中 (qízhōng). However, 其中 means something more like "among the aforementioned," where as 当中 simply means "among." Furthermore 其中 cannot be used in relation to processes.

彼此 (bǐcǐ) is a personal pronoun. 彼 (bǐ) is an archaic word meaning 那 (nà) or "that," and 此 (cǐ) means 这 (zhè) or "this." Therefore, 彼此 (bǐcǐ) literally means "that and this," and is used in modern times to mean "you and me".
Basic Usage as Subject or Object
blocks.text: Basic Usage as Subject or Object

blocks.html: As a personal pronoun, 彼此 (bǐcǐ) is often used as a subject. When used as an object, the verb must be disyllabic and is quite formal in tone.

children.english: We've only met once. We don't know each other well.
We're a team. We should communicate more.
I respect my opponent very much. I hope we both can perform well.
We're a family. We must do a good job looking after each other.
Good friends always spend time with each other.
You're husband and wife. How can you not trust each other at all?

blocks.html: Basic Usage as an Attributive
As a personal pronoun, 彼此 (bǐcǐ) is often used as an attributive, modifying a noun.
Sometimes you can also use 彼此 (bǐcǐ) before a noun to make the meaning of the modified noun more abstract.

children.english: Over the past year, we have witnessed each other's progress.
Everyone is facing hardships, we need to respect each other's efforts.
It had been ten years since we last met. We didn't really know about each other's lives and we were surprised at how the other had changed.
We came to understand each other's needs and didn't argue again.

blocks.html: Using 彼此 Idiomatically
When speaking colloquially, you can repeat 彼此 twice: “彼此彼此”. It's a type of idiom that can mean "Everyone is the same" or "We are both the same".

children.speaker: A
children.english: What a nice home you have.

children.speaker: B
children.english: Same, same!

In classical Chinese, 其 (qí) means 那个, 那, or 那些, and refers to people or things previously mentioned in the sentence. It stands to reason therefore, that  其中 (qízhōng）means "among the aforementioned" or 那里面, and denotes that something belongs to, is or is part of a bigger group. This is a little like "of which" in English, where you can say, "I have three ties, of which two feature Batman."

children.english: I have four cars. Of them, three are BMW's.
There are lonely people everywhere. I am just one of them.
Of these many projects, the most difficult is the environmental project.
You have so many books in your study. Can you give me one of those books?
Of the three umbrellas in the office, two are the boss's.
Of the many people, I only know one of them.
You have never done business before, so you don't know the hardship of it.
Don't laugh at the square dancing aunties. Someday you may become one of them.
Humankind faces many challenges in the 21st century. Among them, the most serious is the problem of the environment.
Although work is sometimes dull, I do find joy in it.

blocks.html: In the last example sentence, 乐在其中 means "to find pleasure in" or maybe "there is joy involved with." This sounds awkward in English, but 其中 is often used in this abstract way.

这个 (zhège) can be used by the speaker to emphasize how one regards something or someone. Using 这个 has a stronger effect, and is used with both making simple declarative statements as well as with rude name-calling.
When maliciously name-calling, you probably want to use "你这个 [mean name]."

children.english: You're such a bad person! You haven't done a single good thing.
He's such a brown-noser. He's kissing up to the boss again.
As for Shanghai, its summers are too hot and its winters are too cold.
What kind of person are you? How could you do this?
This job of his still has a lot of challenges.

You may have learned that 了 (le) follows immediately after a verb to indicate completion (AKA 了1), and comes at the end of a sentence when it indicates a "change of state" (AKA 了2). But 了1 also frequently follows not the verb, but the object after the verb. What are the rules for this? When is it natural and when is it not? That's what this grammar point is about: bringing a bit more depth to your understanding of expressing completion with "le".
Both of these basic structures are possible (and correct), even when 了 is only indicating completion.
If it's a rather short and simple sentence, putting 了 directly after the verb, while not technically incorrect, can make the sentence feel incomplete. For example:

children.english: I had class....
The teacher asked questions....

blocks.html: So for these short sentences, it would be more natural to put 了 after the object. So what are the rules for when to put 了 directly after the verb, and when to put it after the object? That is the point of this article.
When 了 Goes After the Object
blocks.text: When 了 Goes After the Object

blocks.html: So the question now is when it's OK to move the 了 to after the object. It often is. Let's look more closely at the circumstances. Unfortunately, 了 is notorious for evading nice clear rules, but we'll do our best here to provide reliable guidelines for usage.
When the Object is Short, Put 了 After the Object
blocks.text: When the Object is Short, Put 了 After the Object

blocks.html: For these examples where the object is short, it sounds better to put 了 after the object. It's not wrong to put the 了 after the verb, but it sounds a little strange to do so. (It may sound stranger for some examples than others, and native speakers will have varying opinions about which sound the strangest. Ask them!)

children.english: I had class.
The teacher asked questions.
Lili has arrived at the train station.

blocks.html: When the Object is Medium-Length, Put 了 After the Verb or Object
blocks.text: When the Object is Medium-Length, Put 了 After the Verb or Object

blocks.html: Once the object gets a bit longer, it starts to sound OK again to put the 了 immediately after the verb, but it also sounds good to put it after the (not too long) object.

children.english: He filed those reports.
I met my old friend today.
I discovered the secret.

blocks.html: When the Object is Long, Put 了 After the Verb
blocks.text: When the Object is Long, Put 了 After the Verb

blocks.html: Once the object gets long enough, it gets awkward to put 了 at the end. The listener has to wait too long to find out if the verb already spoken has been completed or not. So save your listener the suspense; for long objects, it sounds more natural to put the 了 directly after the verb.

children.english: He has submitted all the reports for today.
I met my old friend today whom I haven't seen for 20 years.
I heard about what happened yesterday at the subway station.

blocks.html: 了 After a Verb with an Object
blocks.text: 了 After a Verb with an Object

blocks.html: You may remember these from your original studies of 了 to indicate completion, but it's worth revisiting them to remind you that there are cases when you shouldn't move 了 to after the object, even when your verbs and objects are relatively short.
When the following conditions are met, 了 is typically placed before the object, which completes the sentence and gives it a tone of completion.
When the object has modifiers, such as an indication of quantity or an adjective, it's not weird to put 了 immediately after the verb.

children.english: He bought a car.
Mom made many dishes.
She wore the most beautiful dress.

blocks.html: Examples Specifying the Time, Place, Purpose, etc.
blocks.text: Examples Specifying the Time, Place, Purpose, etc.

blocks.html: When time, place, manner, or purpose are specified in a sentence, 了 can be used immediately after the verb to indicate completion.

children.english: I saw a movie yesterday.
I had dinner together with my colleagues.
We took photos with pandas in the zoo.
His girlfriend quit her job for him.
They arrived at the South Pole without incident.

blocks.html: When the object has modifiers, such as an indication of quantity or an adjective, it's not weird to put 了 immediately after the verb.
了 (le) can also indicate that one action is completed before another in the future, and this type of 了 is often placed directly after a verb with an object.

children.explanation: future action
children.english: After you have arrived home, call me.

children.explanation: future action
children.english: I will go find you after I get out of class.

children.explanation: future action
children.english: She wants to get married after she graduates.

children.explanation: future action
children.english: I plan to go back to work after having the baby.

blocks.html: Usage of Double 了
In this case, 了 follows both the verb and the object.
If another 了 is added at the end of the sentence, implies that the number in front of the object is already a big number, and that this number could continue to grow.

children.english: They've had four children already.
You've eaten five baozi already.

blocks.html: Giving a Tone of Strong Confirmation
blocks.text: Giving a Tone of Strong Confirmation

blocks.html: If there is another 了 placed at the end of the sentence, it can add a stronger emphasis that the action was already completed, in the same way we might say we "did finish the work" or "already finished the work" instead of just saying we "finished the work."

children.english: I already finished my homework. Do you want to check it?
He already asked the manager, and the manager said yes.

You may have learned that 了 (le) follows immediately after a verb to indicate completion (AKA 了1), and comes at the end of a sentence when it indicates a "change of state" (AKA 了2). But what about when a complement comes after the verb? Does that count as part of the verb or not? The answer, as it often is with 了, is "it's complicated."
Both of these structures are possible, but the second one has fewer acceptable use cases.
The former is more common in informal speech, while the latter is more common in written language and is only used with certain types of complements.
了 After the Complement
This is fine for most verb-complement structures. No real limits here.

children.english: Purchased/bought.
Produced/made.
Finished eating.
Jay Chou's concert tickets are sold out.
The book has been wrapped.
Today I slept for ten hours. It was definitely enough sleep.
The first time I heard this song, it hurt me.
We won the competition.

blocks.html: 了 After a Verb with a Complement
blocks.text: 了 After a Verb with a Complement

blocks.html: While you do NOT do this with result complements (e.g. 完, 好, etc.), it is a very common structure with direction complements in written Chinese.

children.english: stood up
walked upward to
started eating
ran over here
chatted on
I saw someone swim over there.
I picked the peach (and pulled it down).
Xiao Mei started crying when she saw her mother wasn't home.
I drank down a whole cup of water.

blocks.html: The particle 嘛 (ma) can be used for topic marking. It basically allows the speaker to state the topic, then gather his thoughts before making a comment on it. Unlike the sentence-final 嘛 pattern you may know, the following comment may or may not be one the speaker feels is obvious.
Translations for this pattern are going to be a bit looser than for many other grammar patterns.

children.english: Pandas. Everybody likes them.
Well, it's a name brand. It can't be cheap.
It's your first time. You'll get the hang of it soon.
Kids. It's not unusual that they don't understand these things.
The boss is buying. Order whatever you want.
It's Shanghai. All the food here is like this.
It's a competition. It's not possible to not be nervous.
The singer,we both like Jay Chou.
Students should act like students.
When it comes to driving, the most important thing is safety.

title: Softening the tone of questions with "ne"

blocks.html: We have seen before that 吧 can be used to soften the tone of statements, or make commands feel more like suggestions. 呢 works in same way, but it is used to make questions more indirect and uncertain in tone.
呢 Used Successively with 还是
blocks.text: 呢 Used Successively with 还是

blocks.html: 呢 can be used successively in questions using 还是.

blocks.text: Option 1 + 呢 + 还是 + Option 2 + 呢？

children.english: Should I go to Myanmar or Thailand? I have to think a bit!
Should we play video games or go to the bar? I'm OK with either!

blocks.html: The example sentences above almost have a tone that the speaker is talking to him/herself, as the question is not directly asked of the listener. A second verb is only necessary if different from the first verb.
呢 with Questions Involving Interrogative Pronouns
blocks.text: 呢 with Questions Involving Interrogative Pronouns

blocks.html: Interrogative pronouns, of course, include 哪儿，谁，怎么，什么, 为什么, 什么时候, etc.

children.english: I wonder whose pen this is?
I wonder where he's going?
How could that be?

blocks.html: In the previous examples, the speaker has a tone of conjecture, a bit like saying "I wonder" in English. Again, as in the first usage, the question is not directly asked of the listener. Overusing 呢 in your questions can sound a bit feminine, though, so keep this in mind.
呢 with "Verb 不 Verb" Questions
blocks.text: 呢 with "Verb 不 Verb" Questions

blocks.html: If a "verb 不 verb" question is posed without 呢, it can appear as though the speaker is a bit impatient, or is ordering the listener to do something. Tone of voice used is also an important factor here, and adding 呢 can give a tone of uncertainty, which sounds less demanding and more polite.

blocks.text: Subj. + Verb 1 + 不 + Verb 1 + (Verb 2) + 呢？

children.explanation: Said as though demanding an answer, potentially in a hurry.
children.english: Well are you going to go shopping or what?

children.explanation: Less intense, just asking a question.
children.english: Are you going to go shopping?

children.explanation: Said to a child, with the implication that if the milk isn't drunk, there will be consequences, with emphasis placed on 喝
children.english: Are you gonna drink the milk or not?

children.explanation: Perhaps said to a friend, with no implication of coercion. Perhaps you want to clear away their cup.
children.english: Did you want to drink that milk?

children.explanation: Perhaps a manager asking a subordinate. This seems like an order, perhaps implying there will be consequences for not working overtime.
children.english: You're working this weekend, right?

children.explanation: Perhaps a manager asking a subordinate. This is not super direct, as 能 has been added.
children.english: Can you come into work on the weekend?

children.explanation: Much more indirect than the above example, implying the person really does have a choice.
children.english: Would you mind coming in on the weekend?")

blocks.html: Remember: the exact meaning of the above sentences depends on the full context, and tone of voice is very important as well. The interpretations given are just possible examples.

title: Defining upper and lower limits
pattern: 级别 / 次序 / 数目 + 以上 / 以下

blocks.html: To specify "more than" or "less than" a certain amount, or "within" a certain amount, you're going to want to use some of these common words: 以上 (yǐshàng), 以下 (yǐxià), 以内 (yǐnèi), and 以外 (yǐwài). All are "nouns of locality," or 方位词 in Chinese.
以上 and 以下

以上 and 以下 mean "more than"/"above" and "less than"/"below," respectively. Generally they are non-inclusive, meaning that when you say 十岁以下 you mean "less than ten years of age," up to ten, but not including ten years old. In actual usage, however, this fine point may sometimes be fudged a little.

blocks.text: Amount / Level + 以上 / 以下

children.english: Children under the age of 10 do not need to buy tickets.
We need people with two years of working experience or more.
The air in my hometown is good. The PM 2.5 level is generally under 50.
The winter temperatures here go below zero.

children.explanation: This could possibly be inclusive of 3-star hotels. Real-world usage is sometimes imprecise!
children.english: When we go on business trips, we stay at hotels with above a 3-star rating.

children.explanation: This could be written or spoken.
children.english: Following, we will discuss how we should resolve this problem.

children.explanation: This could be written or spoken.
children.english: The above is just my personal opinion.

blocks.html: 以内 and 以外
Literally, 以内 and 以外 mean "within" and "outside." This spatial meaning can be extended to all kinds of abstracted meanings, as you will see below. Note that 以外 often combines with 除了.

blocks.text: [Amount / Time / Place / Scope] + 以内 / 以外

children.english: Must be completed within two days.
Can you deliver in 30 minutes or less?
You cannot park within 50 meters of this building.
Please stand 2 meters or more from this place.

title: Expressing "along with…" with "suizhe"
pattern: 随着 A + 的 + Verb， Subj. + Predicate

blocks.html: 随着 (suízhe) means "along with," "following," or, more formally, "in the wake of." The idea is that one thing is "following" another, reacting along with it.

blocks.text: Subj. + 随着 + Noun + Verb Phrase

blocks.html: 随着 is one of those words that can have a wide range of translations, all highly dependent upon the context.

children.english: The branch swayed ceaselessly in the wind.
Children started dancing to the music.
The pollutants entered the body through inhalation.
The garbage flowed into the sea along with the river.
We started singing along with his playing.

blocks.html: 随着 can also be used in the following structure to indicate that a change in the first part causes a respective change in the second part. In this case, the first part is typically a general trend, like economic development or rising prices.

children.english: With economic development, the people's lives get better and better.
With the rise in oil prices, the price of grain has also increased a bit.
As he has gotten older, he has become even more mature.
As the international status of China improves, Chinese people are becoming more and more confident.
In the wake of an ever-increasing population, the social problems in large cities become ever more numerous.

自从 means "ever since" in English, and is used to express the starting point of an action in the past. It can be followed by phrases using the markers 起 and 以后.
When you need to use 以来 in a more formal or written context, you can add 自, 从, or 自从 (or other similar words) before the time or event to make it into a "sandwich pattern."
自从 is used to mark a starting point in time. The same meaning can be expressed with just 从, but 自从 is more formal.

children.english: Ever since arriving in Hunan I've been more and more able to eat spicy food.
Ever since the economic crisis hit the job market has gotten worse and worse.
Since their fight the two of them haven't spoken at all.

blocks.html: In the above examples, 从 can be used interchangeably with 自从. The main difference is that 从 can also be used to state starting points in the future, a little like "from" in English. 自从 cannot be used in this way.

children.explanation: 从 can be used for future times.
自从 cannot.
children.english: Starting from tomorrow, I'm going to study seriously.

blocks.html: Note that 从 can be used to denote starting points in place and time, whereas 自从 can only be used to express starting points in time.

children.explanation: 从 can be used for physical distances.
自从 cannot.
children.english: From my home to the airport, the distance is 100 kilometers.

blocks.text: 从 / 自从 / 自 + Time / Event + (以)后 / 以来

blocks.html: These words all mean "from," with 从 the least formal, 自从 noticeably more formal, and 自 the most formal. At the end of the structure, 以后 is the least formal, followed by 后, with 以来 the most formal.

children.english: Ever since he broke up with me he hasn't contacted me.
Ever since I've started using my phone to pay for stuff I rarely take cash when I go out.
He hasn't returned home since his father passed away.
She has been teaching Chinese since she graduated.
Tremendous changes have been taking place in China since the reform and opening up to the outside world.
Ever since my little sister was born, mom has been busier than ever.

children.english: This kind of job, for me, is very important.
For her, freedom is even more important.
For people born in the eighties, Internet dating is totally normal.
To you, am I that kind of person?

For an ethnic group, unity can overcome all else.
For consumers, sales promotions are very appealing.
For you this product doesn't have much appeal, right?
For Xiao Ming, this is not merely a prize, but more of an affirmation.
For homosexuals, telling their family their true sexual orientation is not easy.

The word 在内 can be used as a prepositional phrase meaning "including." In addition, the verb 包括 can often be used with 在内 at the beginning of a sentence, equivalent to the English "including."

children.english: These fees are not included.
Did you include your meal stipend?
Everyone has responsibility in this matter, including the government.
Including his native language, he can speak 4 languages.
My monthly rent is 3500, including water and electricity.
This attack caused three deaths, including two policemen.
Xiaomi will launch several new products next month, including Xiaomi TV.
This team, including me, has eight people altogether.
Including the boss, everyone disagrees with this opinion.
Now our online sales are great, including today's sales, the sales volume has already reached 20 million.

凭 (píng) is a preposition that means "on the basis of" or "by virtue of." Usually the subject of a sentence which makes use of 凭 is a person.
凭 with a Noun

凭 can be followed up with a noun or noun phrase. The nouns can be something concrete like a passport, diploma, or official ID, or they can be something abstract like experience, efforts, intuition, etc.

children.english: Using a passport, foreigners can buy train tickets.
He studied more than three thousand Chinese characters through his own efforts.
With our student ID cards, we enjoy a special discount at the movie theater.

blocks.html: 凭 with a Verb Phrase
凭 can also be used with a verb phrase or subject-predicate phrase as follows:

children.english: From the fact that I have studied Chinese for a shorter time but speak it better than you, I can say that I'm smarter than you.
On the basis of Lao Li's twenty years of experience in this industry, he is qualified to be your teacher.
He could tell who was singing just by the sound of the song.
Watching Michael Jackson's videos isn't enough to learn how to dance. You also have to rely on your own efforts.

blocks.html: 凭 with 什么

This is one of the most common ways to use 凭, especially in spoken Chinese. It often has a feeling of dissatisfaction or anger, perhaps said during an argument. It is like saying, "On what basis do you ...!?!?" Usually it is paired with blaming, scolding, attacks, etc.

children.english: On what grounds are you blaming me?
I haven't done anything wrong. What is he yelling at me for?
She's always been honest. On what basis are you suspicious of her?

blocks.html: Structure with 凭着

You can also add 着 to 凭 to make it 凭着, however when you do so you can only use it if the action has already been completed. If the action occurs habitually or has not happened yet, you cannot use 凭着. The structure is the same as using 凭 by itself.

children.english: On the basis of his own hard work, Xiao Bai was able to become rich.
Using his intellect, he was able to overcome many difficulties.

title: Expressing passive voice with "gei"
pattern: Receiver + 给 + The Doer + 给 + Verb Phrase

blocks.html: 给 can be used in passive voice constructions. It can either directly replace 被 or be used together with 被. Compared with 被, 给 is more colloquial and is not used in written language.
Only using 给
给 can directly replace 被 in the original passive pattern.

blocks.text: Receiver + 给 + The Doer + Verb Phrase

children.english: I got scammed by him.
Such a great opportunity has been wasted by you.
All the food has been finished off by you guys?
That kid is totally spoiled by you.
The water here is all polluted.

blocks.html: Using 给 with 被
When using 给 in the passive voice, you can also use it with 被. In this structure 给 gives emphasis to the passive voice. You can find more information at: Advanced uses of 被.

blocks.text: Receiver + 被 + The Doer + 给 + Verb Phrase

children.english: My computer was broken by Xiao Ming.
My younger sister was scared to tears by this movie.
Everyone was attracted by the news.
Don't let your cell phone get stolen by a thief.
Don't be persuaded by parents! You need to stick to your own ideas.
