至于 (zhìyú), meaning "with regards to" or "as to," is used when the speaker wants to comment on a topic related to the previously discussed one.
This structure is used similarly to "with regards to" in English. Just put at the beginning of the sentence, before the further comment you want to make.
Note: 至于 is used after some other discussion or comments. It is not used to start a new discussion free of context.

children.english: I've given the project proposal to my boss. Iit's up to him whether he agrees or not.
He is a good soccer player, but just average at basketball.
I like reading very much. As for what books, there are no limits.
I've already told you a lot. As for this question, just think about it yourself.
That's all I can do for you. As for what to do later, you're going to have to work hard on your own.
I'll definitely go home for Chinese New Year, but as for whether she goes back or not, I'm not involved.
I'll raise the kitten for now, and as for the matter of money, we'll talk about it later.
I've already tried my best. With regards to the results, it all depends on luck.
She told me she was coming back tomorrow. With regards to the specific time, I don't know about that.
A lawyer can only defend her client. As for the verdict, that depends on the judge.

"Limiting scope" is like saying, "what I'm about to say applies to just this." You precede the scope with 就 (jiù) in this pattern.
Indicating Scope with Just 就
"就” can be placed after the subject to indicate the object or scope of the subject's activities such as observation, discussion, analysis, and explanation.

children.english: The two leaders exchanged views on environmental issues.
I would like to make two points on this issue.
Everyone expressed their own thoughts on the development of China's internet.
China's chairman made a statement on China's recent economic reforms.
Education experts from every country had a heated discussion on the best methods of education.

blocks.html: Limiting Scope with 就……来说 / 而言
blocks.text: Limiting Scope with 就……来说 / 而言

blocks.html: 就 (jiù) can be used to limit the scope of a comment, used in the following structure:

blocks.text: 就 + Topic + [来说 / 而言] + Comment

blocks.html: This emphasizes that the speaker is just commenting on that particular topic and nothing else, like "just with regards to" in English. In this sense it is similar to 至于 (zhìyú), but is generally used to introduce a new idea, rather than to move on from a previous related topic.
Note that in the pattern above, 来说 is more informal, and 而言 is more formal.

children.english: As for China's One Child Policy, every expert has their own opinion.
As for the Cultural Revolution, most of the people think it was a disaster.
As a whole, the painting is not bad, but there are some details that need attention.
In regards to these matters, he didn't do anything wrong.
With regards to my family, there are lots of demands on me. For example, we have to be home before twelve o'clock in the evening.

children.english: Taking advantage of the discount, I bought a new phone.

title: Emphasizing a negation with "bing"
pattern: Subj. + 并 + 不 + Verb / Adj.

blocks.html: One of the many uses of 并 (bìng) is to add emphasis to a negative sentence that uses 不 or 没. Because you're emphasizing a negation, 并 is often used when expressing disagreement or pointing out a flaw in someone's argument. While the word 并 is not inherently combative, it can certainly be used that way.
You can take pretty much any sentence with a negated verb and give it a little extra kick with 并. Just put it before the 不 or 没. Note that when used with 不, you can negate an adjective as well.

blocks.text: Subj. + 并 + 不 + Verb / Adj.

children.english: In China, starting a business really isn't easy. There are a lot of challenges.
I'm majoring in finance at the university, but being a financial analyst is not at all my dream.
She's been married for five years and she has a baby, but she doesn't love her husband at all.
What you did didn't actually solve our clients' problems at all.
I've been playing the piano for more than ten years, but I really don't like this musical instrument.
Although I've discussed it with him, we haven't found the problem at all.
I didn't know at all that you called me yesterday.
It rained heavily yesterday, but the weather didn't cool off at all.
Although you said some very harsh things, I didn't get angry at all.
The gift you gave was very expensive, but I didn't like it at all.

title: Expressing "if it were not for" with "yaobushi"

blocks.html: 要不是 (yàobushì) is almost the same as "如果不是⋯⋯ "， and it may followed by "的话," meaning "if it were not for..." or "without...."
The second part of the sentence tells what would have happened otherwise.

children.english: If it weren't for you, I would get lost.
We couldn't have found this place so quickly without her help.
I wouldn't have made this dish if you hadn't said that you wanted to eat it.
I wouldn't have helped him if it were not for him being your friend.
If I didn't have something urgent to do, I would go to the movies with you.
If you hadn't been so busy, we'd have met long ago.
He wouldn't have gotten mad if it weren't for you saying the wrong thing just now.
We would have gotten there long ago if it were not for you all being late.
If Mom hadn't found out, we could have had the get-together at my house.
If it weren't for the traffic jam, I'd be in Shanghai by now.

blocks.html: 多亏 (duōkuī) can be translated as "thanks to" and is used to express that, due to somebody's help, a negative result has been averted. 了 is often placed after it as it's about something that has been completed.
Basic Pattern with 多亏 (了)

children.english: I was able to finish so quickly thanks to your help.
I wasn't late, thanks to you giving me a ride.
I got well quickly, thanks to my mother's care and attention.
Because of you, the project is going smoothly. Thank you.

blocks.html: Pattern with 多亏 and 才
blocks.text: Pattern with 多亏 and 才

blocks.html: When the good outcome comes before 多亏 (as in the pattern above), there is no need to add in 才. But if the good outcome comes after 多亏, you need to add in 才 to indicate "as a result...(the good outcome happened)." (才 gives the sense that the good outcome wouldn't have happened without that extra help.)

blocks.text: 多亏 (了) + [Lucky Incident] ，Subj. 才 + [Good Outcome]

children.english: Thanks to your ride, I'm not late to get here.
Thanks to your umbrella, I didn't get wet.
Thanks to your help, I was able to complete it so quickly.

blocks.html: Advanced Pattern with 多亏 and 不然
blocks.text: Advanced Pattern with 多亏 and 不然

blocks.html: If you want to add in 不然 (bùrán) for an "otherwise... (this really bad thing would have happened)" explanation, use this structure.
When translating to English, "thanks to" doesn't always work as well when you have to add in "otherwise."

children.english: Thank you for reminding me about this matter! Otherwise I would definitely have forgetten.
It was a good thing you took her to the hospital, otherwise her condition could have gotten really serious.
It was a good thing you gave me that suggestion, otherwise I really wouldn't have known what to do.

blocks.html: Difference between 多亏 and 幸亏
blocks.text: Difference between 多亏 and 幸亏

blocks.html: 多亏 (duōkuī) is similar to 幸亏 (xìngkuī) in meaning, the major grammatical similarity being that both can be used with 不然 or 才. But there are a few difference between them:

• Meaning: 多亏 emphasizes a feeling of gratitude towards a specific person for the outcome, rather than attributing it purely to fortune as 幸亏 does.
  • Collocations: 多亏 can combine with just a noun phrase, but 幸亏 can't.
  • Patterns: 多亏 can be placed in the beginning or the middle of a sentence, while 幸亏 can be only placed in the beginning of the sentence.

blocks.html: 而已 (éryǐ) comes at the end of a sentence to express that something is merely what it is. It is like saying "it's nothing more than x."
Pattern with 而已 After a Noun
blocks.text: Pattern with 而已 After a Noun

blocks.html: Whenever you need to emphasize that something is just what it is and that's all, you can stick 而已 at the end of the sentence.

blocks.text: (只是 / 就是 / 才 +) Noun + 而已

blocks.html: You may also see it used in combination with other words like 仅仅，只，就，才 and so on.

children.english: It's just a cup of coffee, you don't need to be so moved.
"Only one thousand yuan?" Don't make it sound so easy.
It's just a TV series. There is no such thing in reality.
There was only one problem, and she started to get angry.
It was just a kiss. It didn't mean anything special.

blocks.html: Pattern with 而已 After a Longer Phrase
blocks.text: Pattern with 而已 After a Longer Phrase

blocks.html: Whenever you need to emphasize that something is just what it is and that's all, you can stick 而已 at the end of the sentence.

blocks.text: Subj. + (只是 / 就是 / 才 / 仅仅 +) Verb + Obj. + 而已

blocks.html: Again, words like 仅仅，只，就，才 are optional, and add more emphasis.

children.english: He's only joking; don't take it seriously.
You only drank one bottle of beer, h. How could you be drunk?
This meeting did not produce a specific plan of action, only an agreement that there was an issue.
All I did was was make a phone call. I didn't help much.
This car is nothing special, it's just an ordinary car.

Adding 什么 (shénme) to the end of a verb can be used to change a sentence into a rhetorical question.
Verb + 什么 + Verb

Just like in English, asking "what are you looking at?" can be a rhetorical question (hinting that you should stop staring), but can also be a sincere inquiry about what exactly the other person is looking at. When you repeat the verb, though, you make it pretty clear that you're not just curious. You're so annoyed that you're asking a rhetorical question.

children.english: Buy what, now? We spent all of our money.
What are you crying for? It's not like there's no gift for you.
What are you laughing at? Does seeing me make mistakes make you happy?
Why are you talking? Everyone else isn't saying a word, it's just you talking.
What are you looking at? Haven't you seen a pretty girl before?

blocks.html: Verb + 什么 + Object
This pattern is often used with separable verbs.
This usage is best illustrated with examples:

children.english: What are you talking about, "divorce"?! You've only been married three months!
No aplogies! You didn't do anything wrong.
Is this some kind of joke? You ran into me, and now you want me to say sorry to you?
What movie can we go see when we're broke?
No time for breakfast. We're going to be late!

blocks.html: Note that the questions above would likely be between friends, or at least two people who are quite familiar with each other. Tone of voice and context is key.

The 比起...来 (bǐ qǐ... lái) structure provides an alternate form and relatively advanced way of making a comparison.
Basic Usage of 比起
In these two structures, 比起... 来 is used to compare A and B, with emphasis on how A is different.
A can also be placed before 比起。

children.english: Compared to Shanghai, the prices in my hometown are way cheaper.
Compared with you, I'm still far from it.
Compared with a doctoral student, an undergraduate student's degree is much lower.

blocks.html: Usage of 相比

blocks.text: 和 / 跟／与 + B + 相比 ，A ……

blocks.html: Note that the following sentence pairs are saying the exact same thing using the two slightly different structures above.

children.english: Compared with online teaching, I prefer face-to-face teaching.
Compared with decades ago, China's rural areas have undergone great changes.
Compared with print advertising, online advertising is not that expensive.
Compared with physical problems, mental problems are more difficult to treat.

不如 (bùrú) can be used to make comparisons in a similar way as the 比 structure. In its simplest form 不如 is used to convey that A is “not as good as” B. Unlike the 比 structure, when used in this way, the adjective or verb can be omitted.

children.english: My older brother's grades are not as good as mine.
Watching a movie isn't as good as reading the book.
He always thinks he's not as good as other people.

blocks.html: When an adjective or verb is added to the structure it can then be used to mean A is not as "adjective" as B, or A does not "verb" as well as B:

blocks.text: A + Verb + 得 + 不如 + B + Adj.
A + Verb-Obj. + 不如 + B+ (Verb + 得) + Adj.

children.english: This dress doesn't look as good as that one.
This saying isn't as practical as that one.
He doesn't dress as well as you do.
I'm afraid that I can't explain it as clearly as you.
He doesn't speak Chinese as authentically as his wife does.
I don't type as fast as you do.

blocks.html: 不如 as an Adverb

When facing a choice, 不如 can also be used to mean "might as well" to emphasize that the choice that comes after 不如 is better than what was just being discussed. When used like this, it is similar in meaning to 不妨 (bùfáng).
不如 often occurs in the 与其……不如…… (yǔqí... bùrú...) structure, meaning "rather than... might as well...." See the grammar point on 与其 for other similar patterns.

children.english: Watching TV at home is so boring! It'd be more fun to go do karaoke.
It's a waste of time for us to wait here. We might as well go out and eat something first.
Rather than fantasizing about it, you might as well take action right away.
Rather than fighting every day, you might as well break up.

The suffix -化 (-huà) can be added to the end of many Chinese words to make them into verbs, the equivalent of "-ize" or "-ify" in English.

You can take some Chinese nouns and adjectives and add a -化 to the end of them to "-ize" or "-ify" them. Basically, -化 takes the noun or adjective and makes it into a verb. One example of how we do that in English is to take the adjective "modern" and add "-ize" to turn it into the verb "modernize." Most of the time, the Chinese words that -化 is added to are two-character words.

The following is a short list of -化 words and sentences. Note that while the suffix -化 most often corresponds to "-ize" or "-ify" in English, these are not the only options in English. (Ah, you gotta love the endless variety of the English language!)

children.english: sinicize/Chinese-ify, Americanize, personalize, digitize, urbanize, polarize, marginalize
We will purify the entire industry.
KFC's Chinese localization has been implemented very successfully.
Deng Xiaoping set forth the Four Modernizations: industrial modernization, agricultural modernization, national defense modernization, and scientific technology modernization.
These days our company's workflows and HR management have already started to be systematized.
beautify, "greenify", soften, modernize, naturalize. diversify
Don't romanticize the truth!
You should allow the butter to soften, then eat it with bread.
We protect the environment in order to beautify our city.
Every year our green[ified] area is expanding.

blocks.html: Part of speech can be quite fluid in Chinese, and using the suffix -化 to change a noun or an adjective into a verb does not mean that verb can't also be used as a noun! So keep in mind that -化 can be not only "-ize" and "-ify," but also "-ization" and "-ification."

children.english: personalize, personalization
modernize, modernization
beautify, beautification

难怪 (nán guài) can mean "no wonder," but when used as a verb can be translated as "hard to blame," a much more literal application. This phrase is usually directed at a person, and it is similar to how in English we may say, "he's always sleepy, but you can't blame him because he works a night shift."
难怪 as a Verb
When used as a verb, 难怪 expresses that the speaker assigns no blame in the situation. Most often a person is placed after 难怪.

children.english: He's late, but we can't blame him for that. The subway broke down today.
Don't blame him, he's just a child. He doesn't know any better.
No one can blame you for this. It's your first time in this place, and you aren't familiar with the local customs.
Don't blame him. He just got here, let's just forget about it.
We can't blame him. He is already seventy years old and is not suitable for high-intensity exercise.
The child smashed his father's favorite vase. You can't blame the father for getting so angry.
If you insist on playing the piano at night, you cna't blame the neighbors for complaining about you.
You're not much of a talker. You can't blame your wife for for saying that talking to you is a total waste of time.
This question was always controversial, so you cna't blame the students for getting it wrong.
You gave the gift that was supposed to be for him to someone else. You can't blame him for being unhappy.

blocks.html: You can see how for some of these examples it wouldn't hard to use a "no wonder" translation. There is definitely a connection between this literal usage and the idiomatic "no wonder" usage.

blocks.html: 将 (jiāng) can be used to denote something is about to happen in the near future, similar to 会, or "will" in English. It is generally used in formal contexts.

title: Combining verbs with "bing"
pattern: Verb Phrase 1 + 并 / 并且 + Verb Phrase 2

blocks.html: 并 (bìng) can be used to connect verbs. In this structure the two verbs should be of equal importance.
The verb phrases in the pattern below are often two-syllable verbs, and usually somewhat formal.
In some cases, the two verb phrases on either side of 并 are of equal stress or importance. When 并 means "moreover," however, it can be replaced with 并且.
Notice that 并且 is used with verbs, unlike 和, which is used mostly with nouns.

children.english: I agree with and support your decision.
We will continue to maintain and carry forward our excellent national traditions.
The meeting discussed and approved the work plan for this year.
Post-Brexit, the U.K. will have to negotiate and sign trade agreements with many countries.
When they overcome the difficulties and succeed, they will feel especially accomplished.

Apple has been operating in Cork since 1980, and has been gradually expanding.
We will work with the partner company to resolve this matter as soon as possible.
The product manager is responsible for working with the engineers to develop the product strategy.
We want to provide our customers with the best possible service, and we want to think about and meet their every need.

难免 (nánmiǎn) means "to be unavoidable" or "inevitable" and is most commonly placed before a verb phrase, often including an auxiliary verb such as 会 or 要. It is normally used to introduce an inevitable situation that is negative.

Young people can't avoid facing setbacks, but the most important thing is to learn how to overcome them.
There‘s no way to not feel excited about it the first time you get on a plane to go abroad.
It's rush hour right now. There's no way to avoid the congestion in the subway.
There's no way for the interns at this firm to avoid doing some random odd jobs.
When you first leave home, you can't help but feel homesick.
There are a lot of people on the bus, so you will inevitably run into thieves. You need to be careful.
When you first start working, you will inevitably make mistakes because you don't have much experience.
Investments can make you rich quickly, but you can't avoid risk.
This is my first time performing, so I can't help but feel a little nervous.

title: Expressing "moreover" with "bingqie"
pattern: Verb Phrase 1 + 并 / 并且 + Verb Phrase 2

blocks.html: 并且 (bìngqiě) can be used to connect two verbs. In this structure the two verbs may be of equal importance (similar to 并), but often the word 并且 is part of a longer pattern which adds in a meaning of "moreover," taking the idea expressed in the first part of the sentence even further.
Simple Pattern Similar to 并
Notice that 并且 is most often used with verbs, unlike 和, which is used mostly with nouns. It is rather formal.
For only this 并且 pattern, you can substitute 并 for 并且 and keep the same meaning.

children.english: I agree with and support your decision.
I can help you find the problem and also solve it.
You need to edit and also print out this document.
Controlling your diet and also exercising more will give you a better and better figure.

blocks.html: Longer Pattern with 也 / 还
blocks.text: Longer Pattern with 也 / 还

blocks.html: The meaning "moreover" means that the second part of the sentence takes the idea in the first part even further.

blocks.text: [Verb Phrase 1] + 并且 + 也 / 还 + [Verb Phrase 2]

blocks.html: You cannot substitute 并 for 并且 in this pattern.

children.english: I need you to do as I say and also do it well.
What we need is an employee with rich work experience and also an understanding of teamwork.
I have informed everyone. Moreover, I have prepared all of the materials.
This type of phenomenon is very common. Moreover, it will also continue for a very long period of time.

blocks.html: Longest Pattern with 不但 / 不仅 + 也 / 还
blocks.text: Longest Pattern with 不但 / 不仅 + 也 / 还

blocks.html: By adding 不但 / 不仅 to the first part of the sentence, this pattern further emphasizes the "moreover" tone of the sentence.

blocks.text: 不但 / 不仅 + [Verb Phrase 1] + 并且 + 也 / 还 + [Verb Phrase 2]

blocks.html: You cannot substitute 并 for 并且 in this pattern.

children.english: My dad criticized me and and also told me that I cannot lie again.
We're in charge of installing and also maintaining this system.

值得 (zhídé) means "to be worth" doing something, and is often placed before a verb or a verb phrase. Note that it is used to describe whether an action is worth it and cannot be used to state that something is worth a certain monetary value. For that 值 must be used on its own.
值得 as an Adverb

children.english: Ba Jin's prose deserves a look.
It's not easy, but it's worth a try.
The spirit of altruism merits some study.
This little thing isn't worth your time.
This house is not worth investing in.

blocks.html: 值得 as a Predicate
值得 can also be used as a predicate all by itself, or following a verb phrase.

children.english: Is it worth it? Yes. It's worth it.
Going to college is really worth it.
Studying Chinese is worth it.
What do you think is worth doing?
Nothing is worth it.

Used mostly in spoken Chinese, 害得 (hàide) can indicate that the speaker is now in some kind of trouble or undesirable situation, caused by someone or something else. There's a tone of blame or complaining when using this pattern.
The reason for the trouble should be stated before 害得 (hàide). The 得 can also be omitted.

Keep in mind that 害得 can be tricky to translate directly. It's more a matter of conveying the tone of "this is how you inconvenienced me" or "this situation negatively impacted me." You might see words like "make" or "force" or "keep from" to communicate that tone.

It's too noisy outside. It's keeping us from focusing on work.
You didn't come back last night, and I couldn't reach you by phone. You made me worry about you for all night.
He took my cell phone without telling me. As a result, I spent all day looking for it.

受 (shòu) is generally thought of as a passive marker, converting the verb placed after it into the passive. Here it plays a role very similar to 被.
受 as a Passive Marker

children.english: Teacher Zhang's lessons are welcomed by the students.
A person don't have to be rich or successful to be respected.
I have been asked to deliver some money to you.
I think I couldn't get through to your cell phone last night because of signal interference.
Affected by a cold front, today Shanghai is especially cold.

blocks.html: It must be noted that if 受 is explained as a passive marker, then in the above examples 欢迎, 尊重, 批评 and 尊重 must all be treated as verbs rather than nouns, despite many of them appearing immediately after 的.
受 as a Verb

An alternative way to explain 受, is as an active verb itself, meaning "to obtain" or "to receive" when dealing with positive aspects, or "to suffer" when dealing with negative aspects. This explanation may be more accessible to native English speakers. However whichever grammatical explanation one uses, the meaning essentially remains the same.

blocks.text: 受 (+ 到/过) + ([Something / Someone] +) Noun / Verb

children.english: Teacher Zhang's lessons received many students' approval.
A person doesn't have to be rich or successful to receive respect from other people.
Neither of my parents has received a very good education.
The first year I was in the USA, I received a lot of help from many friends.
People who traffic kids should suffer severe punishment from the law.
"Suffering" from the influence of a cold front, today Shanghai is especially cold.

blocks.html: It must be noted that on the occasions when 受 is followed immediately by 到 or 过，it is preferable to consider 受 as a verb.

格外 (géwài) is an adverb that has the same meaning as "especially" or "particularly" in English. You might be wondering what the difference between 格外 (géwài) and 特别 (tèbié) is. Keep in mind that 特别 (tèbié) can be either as an adjective that emphasizes something is "special" or as an adverb that expresses "especially." However, 格外 (géwài) can only be an adverb that emphasizes "especially" and cannot be used as an adjective like 特别 (tèbié) can.
You will occasionally see 地 (de) after 格外 and before an adjective.

children.english: It's especially comfortable on mornings after a rain.
I was especially busy today and didn't even have time to eat lunch.
I was tired from climbing yesterday, so my sleep at night was especially sweet.
Last year the kid was very naughty, but this year he's been especially sensible.
I live far away, so it's very quiet at night.
This year's fruit is exceptionally sweet.
I was homesick before too, but I'm especially homesick this time of year.
The teacher is especially warm to us.
Today's weather is exceptionally hot.

倒 (dào) can be used to express something is contrary to expectations, acting as a turning point in the sentence. It is generally followed by a positive comment.
倒 can be used to express an unexpected situation. Note that 倒 is often followed by 也 or 又 to add further emphasis.
Sometimes "actually" works well in translations to indicate the contrast between expectation and reality.

children.english: I helped him not because I liked him, but because he worked very hard.
He's not very hard-working, but his scores also aren't bad.
It's already spring, but it's actually getting colder.
Without taking any medicine, I'm actually slowly getting better.
English is not his mother language, but he speaks quite native-like.

blocks.html: 倒 can also be used to express a concession, mostly emphasizing the positive side. 就是、但是、可是、不过 are often used to precede the undesirable reality the speaker is calling attention to.

blocks.text: Subj. + 倒 ⋯⋯ ，不过 / 但是 / 就是 ⋯⋯

The style and size of this piece of clothing actually work well, but I don't like the color.
Your service is great, but it's too expensive for me.
I really would like to go with you, but you would need to wait until the weekend.

反而 (fǎn'ér) is used to express "on the contrary" or "in contrast," with 反而 appearing as part of the second part of the sentence.  Note that the meaning of 反而 goes beyond just "but" and is usually used to explain that something is totally the opposite of what one was expecting.
Normally the first clause makes a statement, and then the second clause introduces the part that is totally opposite of one's expectations. The word "actually" may be helpful in some translations.

It's also important to point out that 反而 is not a conjunction; it's an adverb. Practically speaking, this means that rather than joining two statements, it goes inside a statement (within the second clause). Specifically, it needs to come after the subject (if there is one) and before the verb. (This is different from a conjunction like 但是 which comes before the subject!) Also 反而 can appear in one sentence with 但是. Rather than replacing it, 反而 can work with 但是 to add even more contrarian emphasis.

children.english: After taking the medicine, the illness actually got even worse.
This new system actually reduced our work efficiency.
He didn't give up; on the contrary, he worked even harder.
Reform actually made the people less satisfied.
Your involvement is actually giving us trouble.

blocks.html: Take note: when the subject of the first and second clause are the same, the subject can be omitted in the second clause (after the comma and before 反而). If there is a subject, however, 反而 definitely needs to come after it. See the simple examples below and then check the longer sentences above, confirming this rule.
Adding 不但 or 不仅 adds a sense of "not only" before the "to the contrary" part. The word "actually" can be useful here for translations into English.

blocks.text: ⋯⋯ ，Subj. [不但 / 不仅] + [不 / 没] ⋯⋯，反而 + [Unexpected Outcome]

children.english: After taking the medicine, the illness not only didn't get better, but actually got even worse.
Having failed so many times, he not only didn't give up, but rather worked even harder.
He not only didn't help me, but rather gave me trouble.
Your mother loves you so much, and not only are you not grateful, but you even say she doesn't care about you?
I took a weight loss pill. Not only did I not lose weight, but rather I actually gained weight!

却 (què) is used to indicate something was contrary to expectations, and is used in a similar way to 倒 (dào). However, 却 is generally followed by a negative comment.
The overall structure of sentences that use 却 is something like this:
Normally the first clause above makes a statement, and then the second clause introduces something contrary, generally in the form of a negative comment.
In the following examples, take note that 却 comes after the subject in each case, and that it can be used together with 但是.

children.english: He's the boss, but nobody listens to him.
He's very well-educated, but his ability is average.
They fell in love at first sight, but they didn't end up with each other.
Although this clothing is brand-name, the quality is not so good.
Some people have high IQ, but really low EQ.
He's only sixteen, but he's much more mature than others his age.

blocks.html: It's also important to point out that 却 is not a conjunction; it's an adverb. Practically speaking, this means that rather than joining two statements, it goes inside a statement (within the second clause). Specifically, it needs to come after the subject and before the verb. (Note that when you use a conjunction like 但是 it comes before the subject! 却 is different in this respect. Also, rather than replacing 但是, it can work with it to add emphasis.)
Sometimes the subject of the second clause will be omitted. If there is a subject, however, 却 definitely needs to come after it.
A few examples to give you a better understanding of this:

children.english: I'm your best friend, but you didn't invite me.
His family is rich, but he never flaunts it.

title: Advanced degree complements
pattern: Adj. + 得 + 很 / 不得了 / 要命 / 不行

blocks.html: There are many ways to express "degree" following a verb. A vast array of words can function as degree complements following verbs, indicating degree and quality. When it comes to degree complements for adjectives, however, options are much more limited.
You should already know complements -死了 and -极了. The following are some of the other more common degree complements which follow adjectives.

• Adj. + 得 + 很
  • Adj. + 得 + 不得了
  • Adj. + 得 + 要命
  • Adj. + 得 + 不行

children.english: This child is super selfish.
My wife's job is extremely easy and relaxed.
My father is awfully stubborn.
He was terribly proud after he won the competition.
Having heard his son was fighting with his classmate again, the father was incensed.
My son is incredibly naughty.
The traffic is terrible!
The metro is so crowded!
My teeth hurt so badly!
It's awfully hot outside.

You may have a handle on the typical potential complements, but there are a few other fairly common ones that you still need to master. Each is addressed separately here, but for all of them, the preceding character 得 (de) or 不 (bu) is pronounced in the neutral tone.
Verbs with -不了 and -得了

This pattern is used to talk about whether or not you are able to do something. It is subtly different from using "不能 + Verb" because "Verb + 不了" usually suggests some external factor out of one's control.
Note that the character 了 here is pronounced "liǎo."

children.english: He's so old. Will he be able to walk that far?
I have things to do tonight. I won't be able to go.
This piece of clothing is too small. I won't be able to wear it.
You're the only one who is able to help me with this.

blocks.html: Verbs with -不下 and -得下
This is used to talk about whether or not something will fit or go somewhere. Commonly used with the verbs 放, 坐, 住, 装, 吃.

children.english: I'm full. I don't feel like eating more.
Can your bag hold that many things?
My car is too small. Five people will not fit in it.
I'm sure my suitcase is big enough for these clothes.

blocks.html: Verbs with -不起 and -得起
This complement is related to being "able to afford" something or some cost. So -不起 means "can't afford to," and -得起 means "can afford to."

blocks.text: Verb + 得起 / 不起 + Obj.

children.english: That piece of clothing is worth two months of your salary. Can you afford to buy it?
This restaurant is too expensive. We can't afford to eat here.
This apartment's rent is at least 10,000 RMB. Can you afford to rent it?
Many people don't have a second child not because they don't want to, but because costs are too high. They can't afford to raise another kid.

blocks.html: Verbs with -不动 and -得动

The potential complement -不动 is used to indicate the lack of energy or physical strength required to do something. This can be used not only with actions like walking, running or climbing, but even actions like eating and chewing.

children.english: I can't keep going. I need to rest a bit.
Wait for me. I can't keep running.
The child is all grown up. His mother can't hold him anymore.
It's so heavy. Can he move it by himself?

blocks.html: Verbs with -不着 and -得着
Similar to -到, the complement -着 (zháo) can denote that someone's one's ability is up (or not) to the task in question.
Note that the character 着 here is pronounced "zháo."

children.english: It's too high. I can't reach it.
It's so noisy. Can you sleep?
It's too hard. I can't guess.

title: Advanced result complements "zhu", "kai", and "chulai"
pattern: Verb + 住 / 开 / 出(来)

blocks.html: Hopefully you're no stranger to the concept of result complements by now, but there are a few that are less common and thus may have escaped direct scrutiny until now. This grammar point focuses on 住, 开, and 出(来) acting as result complements.
住 as a Result Complement
住 can be used after a verb to express a "coming to a halt." These verbs are limited.

children.english: Stop!
Catch that thief!
Excuse me. You're standing in my way.

blocks.html: 住 can also be used to express "undertaking an action firmly."

children.english: You must remember what I said.
You must seize the opportunity tightly.
Hold on! It will be ready soon.
Persevere! Don't give up!

blocks.html: 开 as Result Complement
开 means "to open" or "to turn on." It is used as a complement in this literal sense.

children.english: Open your mouth.
Please open your book.
Please open your eyes now.

blocks.html: 开 can be used to express an action that is occurring in a direction away from the speaker. When used in this sense, 开 is generally used with verbs involving releasing, unfolding or spreading out:

children.english: Go away!
Let go of me!
This good news spread out very soon.

blocks.html: 开 can be also used to express solving a problem or getting a weight off one's mind.

children.english: Cheer up.
Cheer up.

blocks.html: 出(来) as Result Complement
出 and 出来 can be used as complements to figuratively add a sense of "coming into being" or "coming up with."

children.english: What good ideas can you come up with?
These math problems are a little bit difficult. It took me an hour to work them out.
Do you think he can figure out I am the one who did this?
I can't write a ten-thousand-word article.

blocks.html: When paired with verbs related to the senses, the complement 出(来) adds a sense of "to tell" or "to distinguish".

children.english: She must be from the north. I can hear it.
Can you tell how old I am?
The food has MSG in it. I can taste it.
What's this thing made of? Can you tell by feeling it?
Were you smoking? Don't lie to me because I can smell it.

When used as a resultative complement, -着 (zháo) expresses that the action has reached its purpose or has had an outcome. It can also be used as a potential complement, meaning "able to."
All you have to do is put -着 after the verb. Remember that it should be something that you can reach or achieve. It could be a purpose, or it can be producing an outcome or an influence.
Remember: that 着 is pronounced "zháo and not "zhe"!

children.english: The baby just fell asleep.
Did you find your cell phone?
The supermarket is closed. I didn't buy things that you need.
I have finally met you.
I've been so busy lately, he's tired.

blocks.html: You might be wondering: "why the heck would I use this instead of 到?" Hey, excellent question... we like the way you think! But native speakers do use 着 fairly often (especially in the north), so it's something you need to know. Also, 睡着 (shuì zháo), meaning "fall asleep," is an exception in that it is incorrect to say *睡到 to mean "fall asleep."
Potential Complements -得着 and -不着
When used with 得 or 不, 着 functions as a potential complement, and denotes that one's one's ability is up (or not) to the task in question.

children.english: You can't buy such clothes now.
At night when can't get to sleep, I read a book.
I can't find my cell phone.
It's so late already, can we buy it?

You probably learned the result complement -到 a long time ago, as part of words like 看到 ("to see") and 听到 ("to hear"). But other times it's less clear what the -到 really means. Like the difference between 买 and 买到 or 做 and 做到. What -到 adds is a clearer message that something has really been achieved.

Adding -到 after a verb makes it very clear that the desired result was achieved. If you looked and you saw, then 到 indicates that. On the other hand, not adding 到 makes it unclear whether or not the desired result was achieved. It can have the effect of making a verb mean "try to verb." So 做 without -到 is kind of like "try to do," but when you want to make it very clear that results were achieved or must be achieved, that's when you want to add -到.

Let's look at another example. The difference between 找 and 找到 is that 找 means "to search" (in other words, "to try to find"), whereas 找到 means "to find," that the search was successful, and results were achieved. So if one were to say "你一定要找," it would mean "you must try to find it" and "你一定要找到" means "you must find it."
做 vs. 做到
It's often assumed that if you're going to 做 something, it'll be to completion. But if there's ever any doubt, or a situation where "to completion" needs to be made crystal clear, use 做到.

children.english: I haven‘t done it.
I can do it next week.
I believe you will be able to do it.

blocks.html: 买 vs. 买到
买 is another one where success is normally assumed, but every now and then it's not so easy to just buy something. That's where 买到 comes in handy.

children.english: I haven't bought it yet.
I wasn't able to buy it.
You can't buy imported good here.

blocks.html: 学 vs. 学到
You know how when you're studying, you know information is going into your brain, but you're not sure how well it's really sticking? Well, when you're sure of what's stuck, you can use 学到.

children.english: I want to study Chinese.
Today we studied many new words.
Working for this company, I learned a lot of things.

blocks.html: 拿 vs. 拿到
A simple act of physically picking something up or taking something usually involves 拿. When the object becomes some kind of hard-to-get document, however, 拿到 is useful.

children.english: You take the small bag, I'll take the big bag.
I'm not sure when I'll be able to get my work visa.
If he can't get a green card, I will break up with him.

blocks.html: 想 vs. 想到

If you think of 想 as "looking for ideas," then 想 and 想到 are very similar to 找 and 找到. One difference, though, is that 没想到 means "never imagined." It's not that you tried to think of something and failed, it's just that the idea never occurred to you.

children.english: You have to think of a way.
Have you thought of anything good yet?
None of us imagined that he would be so mad.

blocks.html: 追 vs. 追到

This one is tricky, because "pursue" is a metaphor, and there's no obvious result. "Catch" sounds way too misogynistic and old-fashioned. 追到 actually involves more than just effort on the part of the pursuer; you have to move the girl's (or guy's) heart.

children.english: How do you pursue a  girl?
That girl, did you win her over yet?
If you can really win her over, I'll treat you to drinks.

blocks.html: 了解 vs. 了解到
了解 indicates some kind of deep understanding, often one that only comes over a long period of time. But if you suddenly get some new in-depth information, 了解到 may be appropriate.

children.english: I don't really know this person well.
We just acquired some new information.
I learned the real truth of the matter from him.

blocks.html: 联系 vs. 联系到
You can think of 联系 as "initiate contact" and 联系到 as "establish contact."

children.english: How do we get in contact?
Do you have his contact information?
I wanted to get in touch with you, but could never reach you.

blocks.html: This structure can be used if want to say you are "verbing without a clear direction."  It's sort of like "verbing this way and that." The same verb is repeated before the 来 (lái) and 去 (qù). So for example, 走来走去 is a bit like "walking here and there" or "walking this way and that."
The same verb should repeat in this pattern. Single-syllable verbs are most common.
In a sentence, this structure looks like this:

He's been yakking a lot, but he still hasn't admitted that he's wrong.

My classroom style with the kids is quite active. We often do arts and crafts, and sometimes also jump all around.

只要……就…… (zhǐyào... jiù...) means "as long as... then...." In other words, whenever A happens, B (always) results.

Use this structure to express that "as long as" [something happens], "then" [something else will happen]. In logic, this is referred to as a "sufficient condition," meaning that it may not be the only way to bring about the these specific consequences, but it is one reliable way.

children.english: As long as you really like it, I will buy it for you.
As long as you study hard, you'll make progress.
As long as you are here, I won't be worried.
Whenever it rains, she will be in a bad mood.
Whenever she sees her mother, the baby stops crying.
As long as you have finished your work, there is no need to do overtime.
As long as your mother agrees with you going to Beijing, I have no issue with it.
As long as traffic isn't bad, we can get there on time.
As long as you won't get mad, I'll tell you.
As long as your requirements are reasonable, we can consider them.

一旦 (yīdàn) is used to express what would happen after a certain condition is met. Usually it is used with 就. This grammar pattern expresses that "once" one thing happens, "then" something else will happen.
This structure is similar to the English "once... then," as in "once I get my hands on you, you'll wish you'd never been born."

children.english: In case of an accident, you're responsible!
Some people change as soon as they have money.
Once your company goes public, you'll be a rich man.
This table isn't very stable. If there's even a small vibration, it will fall over.
Computer science students are very confident. Once they graduate, they will be able to find good jobs.
You absolutely must not trade stocks in an economic bubble. Once the market collapses, you will regret it!
Once a decision is made, there are no more excuses, and all you can do is take it seriously and do it.
Once you're in a comfortable environment, you don't want to keep trying.
If you raise your prices, you will lose a lot of customers.
This disease is very complicated and once you've contracted it, it's hard to cure.

blocks.html: These patterns using 才 are loosely related, and revolve around a meaning of "only when," "only after," "only then," or "not until." They suggest a condition without stating the condition as explicitly as in the pattern 只有……才…….
才 as "Only When" or "Only After"

In these examples, you'll notice that the first half of the sentence involves some kind of "difficulty," usually involving spending a lot of time, money, or effort. The second half tells what was finally achieved after spending all that time, money, or effort. The English translation which tends to work most reliably for these sentences is "only after," but multiple translations are possible.

children.english: Only after spending 8000 RMB was I able to buy all the things for the trip.
Only after putting a lot of thought into it was Xiao Ming able to design this poster.
Only after many years was he able to forgive his mom.
I had to read that book twice to understand it.
Only after making three trips to Beijing was I finally able to meet that client.
Only after searching for quite a few months was he able to find a suitable apartment.

blocks.html: Note that for each of these examples, events have already occurred. The fuller 只有……才…… pattern is more appropriate for the future or for hypothetical situations.
This use of 才 is quite similar to the 才 used to express lateness. The two sort of blend together.

Note that rather than following a set pattern, the English translation sentences below make use of a number of different translations. "Not until," "didn't... until," "only then," and "only after" may all be appropriate, depending on the context of the original Chinese.

children.english: Not until she finished her homework did she go to sleep.
He didn't realize he had forgotten to bring his key until after he had locked the door.
I finished off the milk, and only then did I discover that it was expired.
Only after her mom called did the baby stop crying.

只有 (zhǐyǒu) means "only if," and is used with 才 (cái) to emphasize that only one course of action will bring about the desired outcome.
Full Pattern with 只有 and 才
blocks.text: Full Pattern with 只有 and 才
只有 + Essential Condition + 才 (能) + Desired Outcome

blocks.html: Note that 才 is often followed by 能, but not always. This pattern is usually used for hypothetical situations, and is used what is in logic called a "necessary and sufficient condition," meaning "if and only if...."

children.english: Only if you work hard is it possible to do a good job.
Only if you eat more will you be able to grow tall.
Only if you speak more will your Chinese improve.
Only if everyone works together can we succeed.
Only if you finish your homework can you watch TV.
Only if Mom is here can we go out and play.
Only if you go running every day can you have a healthy body.
We can only do this if the boss agrees with the suggestion.
You can only tell if it's good or not if you have eaten it before.
Only if you have learned pinyin can you learn Chinese characters better.

blocks.html: Note that for each of these examples, events have not already occurred. If they have, consider using the "only after" 才 pattern which doesn't use 只有.
Short Form with 才 Only

This is one of the simpler 才 patterns, providing a way to emphasize that it's THIS one (not THAT one). There's no "only if" here, but the 只有 is still implied in Chinese (meaning "it is only"). While this pattern has many uses, one of the most common (and most childish) is as a not-so-witty comeback, in the form of, "no, YOU are!"

children.english: YOU're the idiot!
In some western countries, it's only white people that are the "real" westerners. I don't agree.

除非 (chúfēi) can be used as a conjunction and means "unless." 否则 (fǒuzé) or 要不然 (yàobùrán) often appear in the following phrase, to form a construction meaning "unless x, otherwise y":
Pattern with 除非
The simplified construction more directly maps to the basic English usage of "unless," as in, "I won't do it unless you pay me."
The sentences below place emphasis on the part after 除非.

children.english: I won't go unless you go too.
You can't come in unless you have an appointment.
I won't tell you unless you promise me you won't get upset.
You won't get promoted so soon unless you perform very well.
The company won't allow its staff time off unless they have a really good reason.

Teacher, we need you to give us a little hint. Otherwise, none of us will be able to figure out the answer.

即使⋯⋯也⋯⋯ (jíshǐ... yě...) means "even if... still...." In this construction, the first clause (after 即使) is a supposition, which is then struck down as impossible by the second clause (after 也) of the statement.

children.english: Even if you don't want me to go, I still have to go.
Even if it is very cold in winter, Jake won't wear a jacket.
Even if he doesn't have money, I'm still going to marry him.
Even if you were very rich, you couldn't buy happiness.
Even if you don't have any appetite, you still need to eat something.
Even if you are not so interested in this subject, you still need to study it.
Even if she had plastic surgery, I could still recognize her.
Even if they want to compensate us, we're still going to make this public.

blocks.html: Note that the clause used after 即使 must be hypothetical, otherwise 虽然 should be used.

children.english: Although it's busy now, we still take time to accompany the children.

blocks.html: In the sentence above, the first part is the actual current situation, so it is incorrect to use 即使.

就是 (jiùshì) is one of the many "even ifs." Like 即使 , 就算 and 哪怕 it is used to introduce a hypothetical statement, which can then disregarded with 也.

Even if the temperature is dropping, I'm still going to wear hot pants. They're fire!
Even if he were penniless, I would still be willing to be with him.
Even if it it's going to fail, I want to give it a try.

Even if I get fired, I still don't want to do anything illegal.
Even if you buy a car, I still will not marry you.
Even if there is no one on the road, you shouldn't run a red light.
Even if it makes you angry with me, I still need to tell him about it.

children.english: Although it's rush hour now, I'm still going out.

blocks.html: In the sentence above, the first part is the actual current situation, so it is incorrect to use 就是.

就算 (jiùsuàn) is an informal way of saying "even if," and is used to introduce a hypothetical statement. However, unlike 即使 , 哪怕 and 就是, 就算 has more of a feeling that the speaker doesn't believe that the hypothetical statement is reasonable or has much chance of being realized.

children.english: Even if you don't want to listen, I still need to say it.
Even if what you say is true, we still don't have any way to prove it.
Even if I fail, I won't regret it.
Even if he says it's his treat, I'm still going to pay.
Even if you pass the interview, you still won't necessarily be hired.

We should carry on no matter how difficult it is.
I can't do anything illegal, no matter how much you pay me.

哪怕 (nǎpà) means "even if," and has a slightly stronger tone than 即使 or 就算. It is therefore often used to disregard hypothetical statements of a more serious nature.
The basic "even if" form should be familiar if you know 即使 or 就算.

children.english: Even if he doesn't say, I'll still find out.
It would make her really happy even if you didn't buy any present.
I wouldn't marry him even if his father were the president!
Even if it will make you guys unhappy, I still need to say this.
Even if you dressed up like a movie star, he still wouldn't pay you the slightest attention!

blocks.html: Advanced Pattern with 再
哪怕 is often followed by 再 to further emphasize that what follows won't make a difference. In this usage, it's very similar to "no matter," which can also be expressed by patterns like 不管 (bùguǎn).
If the two subjects are the same, it's OK to omit one.

children.english: Even if I‘m super busy, I will still find some time to work out.
No matter how convincing you are, we're still not going to believe it.
Even if it's really exhausting, she doesn't want her parents' help with the baby.

要是⋯⋯，就⋯⋯ (yàoshi..., jiù...) is one of several ways to convey "If..., then..." It is very similar to 如果..., 就... in usage and formality. However, it is important to note that 要是 is considered to be even more informal (and is usually left more to spoken Chinese) than the common 如果 and used more frequently in the northern areas of China.
Note that the subject can also be placed before 要是. In this case, 要是 can be shortened as 要.

children.english: If you do miss me, then give me a call.
If my mother knew about this, I would be so dead!
If the boss doesn't agree, then we can't sign the contract with the client.
If you keep talking that way, I'm really gonna get angry.
If he doesn't listen, there's nothing I can do about it.

If it weren't for your reminding me, I would have forgotten.

Literally meaning "ten thousand [to] one," 万一 (wànyī) is a word you can use to discuss unlikely possibilities in the sense of "what if," or "in case," or "in the unlikely event that." It's most often used to bring up undesirable situations.

万一 is used for a usually undesirable possibility which the speaker considers highly unlikely. It's often a rhetorical question. (In other words, the speaker is saying, "if this happens, you're screwed.")
There are two common ways to use it in a question:
Note that 万一 can go before or after the subject of a sentence.
This use of 万一 has the same basic meaning as in a statement, but because it's a question, there's no solution offered.

children.english: What if my parents disapprove?
What if we get caught?
Take an umbrella. What if it rains?
You should call first. What if he's not there?
Drive more slowly! What if you hit someone?

blocks.html: After bringing up the possibility of "disaster," the rest of the sentence normally addresses what "we" should do about it.

children.english: If he doesn't like it, you can come back and exchange it.
I need to write it down. In case I forget, I can look it up.
In case you get lost, use the map's GPS navigation.
In the unlikely event that this happens, call the police immediately.

不管 (bùguǎn) is more informal than 无论, but it is used in more or less the same way. As with other constructions, 都 and 也 can be used in the second part of the sentence to emphasize the action or decision will not change.

No matter if you agree or disagree, I'm still going.

children.english: No matter how expensive it is, I'm buying it.
No matter how far it is, I'm going with you.
No matter how difficult it is, you can't give up.
No matter how well-dressed I am, he doesn't take a look at me.
No matter how their children misbehave, parents shouldn't hit them.

title: Expressing "no matter" with "wulun"
pattern: 无论 / 不论⋯⋯，都 / 也⋯⋯

blocks.html: 无论 (wúlùn) means "no matter," and is generally used in the first part of the sentence. As with many other constructions, 都 and 也 can be used in the second part of the sentence to emphasize the action or decision will not change. It is more formal than 不管.

blocks.text: 无论 + Circumstances + 都 / 也 + Inevitable Result

blocks.html: Note that 不论 (bùlùn) is equivalent to 无论 for this pattern.

Because 无论 means "no matter," the clause that follows 无论 is going to include phrases such as "how hard you try" or "wherever you go," and thus will normally include interrogative pronouns such as 怎么, 多(么), 什么, 谁, etc.

children.english: No matter how successful he is, he always thinks he isn't enough.
Wherever you go, I will follow you.
Whether you speak up or not, the result will be the same.
No matter what you do, I don't like it.
No matter how many messages you send him, he won't reply.
You have to work overtime whether you want to or not.
Whether I'm at home or not, you can leave the package at the door.
No matter how much medicine he takes, he doesn't get better.
Whether you go or not, I will go.
No matter what happens, he will give up. Don't overestimate him.

blocks.html: 无论如何 (wúlùn rúhé) is a useful set phrase, meaning "no matter what."

Once you've gotten the hang of the basic 把 (bǎ) sentence pattern, you can start to use it in some more complex and abstract ways.
Using 把 with 给

This 给 is used in oral Chinese to add emphasis to the verb. The 给 is actually fully optional, but it's good to be familiar with this pattern because it's so commonly used in spoken Chinese. You'll notice a structural similarity to this 给 used with 把, and the 给 used with 被.

blocks.text: Subj. + 把 + Obj. + 给 + Verb Phrase

children.english: I forgot about this matter.
On weekends, I wash the dirty clothes.
Will you be able to memorize all of this?
He dropped my phone and broke it.
Mom threw away all of the useless stuff.

blocks.html:
• 我 把 这 事儿 给 忘 了 。Wǒ bǎ zhè shì er gěi wàng le.I forgot about this matter.
  • 周末 我 把 脏 衣服 给 洗 了 。Zhōumò wǒ bǎ zāng yīfu gěi xǐ le.On weekends, I wash the dirty clothes.
  • 你 能 把 这些 都 给 记住 吗？Nǐ néng bǎ zhè xiē dōu gěi jì zhù ma?Will you be able to memorize all of this?
  • 他 把 我的 手机 给 摔坏 了 。Tā bǎ wǒ de shǒujī gěi shuāi huài le.He dropped my phone and broke it.
  • 妈妈 把 没用 的 东西 都 给 扔了 。Māma bǎ méiyòng de dōngxi dōu gěi rēng le.Mom threw away all of the useless stuff.
Using 当作 and 看作
blocks.text: Using 当作 and 看作

blocks.html: When you want to say that something is treated as something else, use this pattern.

blocks.text: 把 + Obj.+ 当成 / 看成 / 当作 / 看作 +⋯⋯

blocks.html: So what's the difference between using 当成 / 看成 / 当作 / 看作?  Good question. The differences are not huge, but there are a few:

• The 成 versions are a bit less formal than the 作 versions.
  • 看成 / 看作 is often followed by a person or specific thing, whereas 当成 / 当作 is more likely to be followed by something more abstract (like 爱).
  • The 成 / 作 part of 当成 / 当作 can be dropped in spoken Chinese, whereas the 成 / 作 part of 看成 / 看作 can never be dropped.

children.english: I have always seen him as my older brother.
He treated my house like his own.
Many foreign students treat their Chinese teachers as their friends.
Kids can take small things in the house and treat them as as toys.
Many kids make their parents' ideals their own ideals.

blocks.html: Take Things Seriously with 当回事
blocks.text: Take Things Seriously with 当回事

blocks.html: 当回事 is mostly used in colloquial Chinese. It means to take something seriously or to hold something in high regard. It is usually used with the negative 不.

blocks.text: (别 / 不）把 + Obj. + 当回事

children.english: He never takes what his boss says seriously.
You always take yourself way too seriously.
Some parents never take their kids' minor problems seriously.
Our class has a few students who never take the teacher's homework seriously.

blocks.html: Using 把 with a verb + 成
blocks.text: Using 把 with a verb + 成

blocks.html: In this case, 成 can be translated as "into."

blocks.text: 把 + Obj. 1 + Verb + 成 + Obj. 2

blocks.html: In the first example, we are using concrete verbs such as 切, 做, 分, etc. on Obj. 1. Naturally, the resulting Obj. 2 should also be concrete.

children.english: Please cut the cake into six parts.
I know how to make this picture into a video.
The teacher divided the whole class of students up into three groups.

blocks.html: In the example below, we are dealing with more abstract objects and verbs. These verbs include 换, 变, 改, 看, 当, 转, etc.

children.english: Every month, I have to convert this USD into RMB.
She converted her house into her workspace.
Can you convert this file format into a PDF?
The South Korean government changed the capital name from "Hanseong" to "Seoul."
Please translate these sentences into Chinese.

blocks.html: The example below is when somebody mistakes something for something else. This can be either mishearing, misspelling, seeing something as something else, etc. These verbs include 看, 听, 写, 记, etc.

blocks.text: 把 + Obj. 1 + Perception Verb + 成 + Obj. 2

blocks.html: So Obj. 1 is the actual thing, and Obj. 2 is what it is mistaken for.

children.english: He misread 太 as 大.
Just now you misread "zhèngfǔ" as "zhàngfu".
I often write the 己 in 自己 like the 已 in 已经.
Did you mishear "party" as "wait in line"?

title: Advanced uses of "lian"
pattern: 连 + Verb + 都 + 不 / 没 + Verb (，就 ⋯⋯)

blocks.html: 连⋯⋯都⋯⋯ (lián... dōu...) is a pattern that can be used to emphasize certain unexpected or surprising events or information, like "even" in English.
连 as "Not at All"
Using this type of sentence structure emphasizes "not even... at all...."

blocks.text: 连 + Verb + 都 + 不 / 没 + Verb (，就 ⋯⋯)

blocks.html: Note that the two verbs in this pattern are the same verb. It repeats.

children.english: Friends? I've never even met this person.
Why are you taking other people's stuff without even asking?
He just left without even saying anything.
You guys didn't even taste it at all and you say it's not good?
You gave this book away without even reading it first.

blocks.html: 连 as "Not Even One"
Here 连 serves as an adverb to add emphasis. It can also be omitted.

blocks.text: 连 + 一 + Measure Word (+ Noun) + 都 + 不 / 没 + Verb

children.english: He couldn't even say a sentence in Chinese two years ago.
He doesn't even have a single suit?
We haven't met even once.
I haven't gotten even a single bite of cake.
Xiao Ming has never taken a train even once.

You might wonder why you have 不比 (bù bǐ) for negative comparisons when you already have 没有 (méiyǒu) for comparisons. The answer is that they're not exactly the same thing! 没有 should be your "go to word" for expressing "not as... as...," but there are cases where 不比 (in all of its subtle glory) is a better choice.
The Difference between 不比 and 没有
blocks.text: The Difference between 不比 and 没有

blocks.html: 不比 and 没有 are not exactly the same. 没有 means "not as... as," whereas 不比 is a direct negation of 比, meaning "not more... than." Compare the following two English sentences:

• You're not as smart as me. (没有)
  • You're not smarter than me. (不比)
You'd probably be more upset to hear the former from a friend than the latter.  The two above sentences in Chinese are:

children.explanation: I am definitely smarter than you; we're not equal in smarts.
children.english: You're not as smart as me.

children.explanation: You're no smarter than I am, but we might be equal in smarts.
children.english: You're no smarter than I am.

blocks.html: Basic Pattern with 不比
To say that something is not more adjective as another, you can use 不比 (bù bǐ). No snickering, please. This is similar to, but not exactly the same as comparing with 没有.

children.english: You're no worse than me.
You're not dumber than anyone else.
His wife's salary is no lower than his is.
Shanghai is no cheaper than New York .
Some people think that it's no easier to raise a pet than to raise a child.

blocks.html: Pattern with 不比 and an Adjective
blocks.text: Pattern with 不比 and an Adjective

blocks.html: If it's more about the degree of an action, use this pattern below:

blocks.text: A + 不比 + B + Verb + 得 + Adj.

blocks.html: Note that "Verb + 得" can also placed before 不比.

children.english: You sing no worse than the singer does.
He calculates no slower than the computer.
She dances no worse than a star.

The 要⋯⋯就⋯⋯ grammar structure can be used to express the same meaning as 如果⋯⋯就 However, 要⋯⋯就⋯⋯ is more intense and resolute, similar to imperative sentences (command sentences). Therefore, 要⋯⋯就⋯⋯ sentences typically do not have a subject, but they can have a topic. This grammar form is similar to the English "If you want to (verb) just (verb)..."
Note that the verbs in this pattern are usually single-syllable verbs.

children.english: If you want to leave, leave. We don't need you.
If you're going to buy it, buy it now. We are about to close the shop.
If you're going to say it, say it now. Don't talk behind people's backs.
If you want to go, go now. You don't need to wait for us.
If you want to eat, eat. Don't just snack.

blocks.html: It's possible to modify the second verb a little bit as well, as long as it's short.

children.english: If you want to go, go fast.
If you want to eat, go ahead and grab some.
If you want to study it, study it well.
If you want to ask, then ask clearly.
If you want to buy it, buy it soon.

title: Expressing "any" with "renhe"
pattern: 任何 + Noun + 都 / 也 ……

blocks.html: 任何 (rènhé) is a modifier that means means "any," "whichever," or "whatsoever." It is also like the English phrases "any and all" or "no matter what."
This modifier usually does not use 的. It is often paired with 都 or 也.

blocks.text: 任何 + Noun + 都 / 也 ……

children.english: After you arrive at the party, don't drink anything.
The road is under repair. No cars are allowed to pass here.
This is our secret. Don't tell it to anyone.
My parents won't let me participate in any extracurricular activities.
So many years have passed, and he hasn't changed a bit.
You can't let this kind of thing happen under any circumstance.
You are always welcome in our house. You can come by anytime.
This is a very important project and no accidents are to happen.
Our boss is a very good person. Any thoughts you have you can discuss with him.
I need to go now. Call me if you need anything at all.

既 (jì) can be used in conjunction with either 又 (yòu) or 也 (yě) to express that something is "both A and B":
Used with 又
A and B can be adjectives, verbs or short phrases. Most of the time A and B will be of the same form. It often sounds better one both A and B are single syllables or both are two syllables.

children.english: This colleague is both proactive and hard-working.
This restaurant is both cheap and delicious.
He does things both quickly and well.
This bank's service is both enthusiastic and thorough.
This product's design is both stylish and user-friendly.

blocks.html: Used with 也
The structure can also be formed with 也, but here it is used primarily for verbs or verb phrases:

children.english: This is both your hometown and mine.
She is both my mother and my friend.
The requirement is that you need to speak both fluent Chinese and English.
Do not meddle in it, for it is neither your business nor mine.
Dad was really mad at me, but he neither hit me nor yelled at me.

title: Expressing "can't do without" with "shaobuliao"
pattern: Subj. + 少不了 + Noun / Verb Phrase

blocks.html: In the phrase 少不了 (shǎobuliǎo), the word 少 represents "being without." So 少不了 means "can't be without" or "can't do without." It is quite colloquial in usage.

blocks.text: Subj. + 少不了 + Noun / Verb Phrase

children.english: Every Chinese New Year, it's gotta be dumplings and the Spring Festival Gala.
If I get home late, there's no getting out of getting yelled at.
On someone's birthday we can't not eat birthday cake.
Studying Chinese always involves studying pinyin and Chinese characters.
When you return home for Chinese New Year, you can't fail to bring back some presents for your family.
We're all neighbors, so we'll definitely have to trouble you at some point.
He is responsible for contacting clients, so he invariably has to treat them to dinner.

blocks.html: Pointing to a Cause with 少不了
blocks.text: Pointing to a Cause with 少不了

blocks.html: Sometimes the two things that 少不了 connects can be events, saying "It's like A because B happened." This construction is often based on observations or experiences that the speaker has had, so that they can know (or assume) what situations relate to each other. It is often used together with 是.

blocks.text: Situation / Result ，少不了 + 是 + Reason

blocks.html: Note, however, that in this construction, the reason follows 少不了.

children.english: Look at him. He must have argued with his girlfriend.
It's so stuffy. It must be about to storm.
It's past 8 o'clock he still hasn't come back. He must be working overtime.

Wasting your time is wasting your life.
Eating half of a watermelon is equivalent to eating three bowls of rice.
If you go, it's the same as if I went.
Money is not equal to happiness, you should think about it carefully.
If a country does not develop its economy, it is giving its rivals an opportunity.
To do this amounts to giving him the money.
Growing old is not equivalent to maturing. Maturity is being responsible for what you have done.

The result is the knowledge, information, or experience gained from the "source."

children.english: I learned a lot from the book.

Xiao Wang knows the importance of honesty from this matter.
We found a lot of stuff from the nineties in the old house.

Lili found out from WeChat that her husband was talking to another woman.
I found an error in the article.

I gained a lot of friendship from this competition.

One of the many uses of 就 (jiù) is to add emphasis to indifference. This is similar to when we say in English "if you want to do it, then just do it!" and swapping out the "do" in that sentence for some other verb.
If you've learned to express "as one likes" with 就, then this pattern should feel familiar. It has a very different tone, however, better suited to higher-level learners.
This structure will usually add emphasis to what are saying, and it often expresses that the speaker has an "I don't care" attitude.
Note that the verb in this pattern is the same one repeating.

children.english: If it's broken, leave it there. We can buy a new one.
Sure, I'll leave. I wanted to quit a long time ago!
If they oppose it, let them oppose it. I don't care.
If you want to take a bet, let's take a bet. You think you scare me?
If you want to get a divorce, let's do it. I wanted to do this a long time ago!

blocks.html: The 不 in this pattern can also be replaced with 没.

I'm fine with not eating. You think I really want to eat?
Fine, don't help if you don't want to. You're not the only friend that I've got.
You just really don't get it. There's no point in me explaining so much.
It's fine that he didn't show up. I can handle it by myself.

title: Expressing "not even one"
pattern: 一 + Measure Word + (Noun) + 也 / 都 + 不 / 没 + Verb

blocks.html: In English we might want to say something like "I have absolutely no money, not even one penny." Expressing that "not even one" can take one of several forms, all of which are common in everyday Chinese.
This structure is usually used for emphasizing how little of something there is. The measure word in the middle of the sentence and the noun should be compatible with the verb at the end.

blocks.text: 一 + Measure Word + Noun + [也 / 都] + [不 / 没] + Verb

children.english: He didn't say a thing.
He can't speak one sentence of Chinese.
Why is there not a single person here?
I haven't had a single bite.
He didn't have a single foreign friend before coming to Shanghai.
She didn't drink a single bottle of cola.
I don't know a single thing.

blocks.html: If you want to put the topic of your conversation at the beginning of the sentence, make sure the comment which follows has a strong emphasis or some kind of extreme quality.

blocks.text: Topic + Subj. + 一 + Measure Word + Noun + [也 / 都] + Verb

children.english: I've never met this person even once.
I've never eaten this kind of food before.
Not one person in our company has participated in this activity.

title: Expressing "not only..., even..." using "budan..., shenzhi lian"
pattern: Subj. + 不但 ⋯⋯ ，甚至连 + New Subject + 也 + Matching Situation

blocks.html: Think of the "不但……, 甚至连……也……" (bùdàn... shènzhì lián... yě...) structure as a cousin to the various "not only..., but also" structures. The only difference is that this structure uses 甚至连 (shènzhì lián) to express "not only..., but even."

title: Expressing "related to..." with "you guan de"
pattern: 跟 / 和 + Topic + 有关的 + Noun

blocks.html: When you need to express one thing in relation to another, the word 有关 (yǒuguān) can be a useful way of making a noun more specific. It comes in two flavors: the "跟……有关的" (gēn... yǒuguān de) structure, which is informal, and the  "与……有关的" (yǔ... yǒuguān de) structure, which is formal.
Informal Pattern with 跟 or 和
blocks.text: Informal Pattern with 跟 or 和

blocks.html: The more casual form uses 跟 or 和. Use this in your spoken Mandarin.

blocks.text: 跟 / 和 + Topic + 有关的 + Noun

children.english: We broke up, I don't want to know anything related to him.
He is very interested in China, he is interested in anything related to Chinese history.
Any information related to this project needs to be kept confidential.
I want to know everything about this person.

blocks.html: Formal Pattern with 与
In more formal contexts, you will see the pattern used with 与 (yǔ).

blocks.text: 跟 / 和 + Topic + 有关的 + Noun

children.english: I would like to participate in any activity related to the game.
He has learned a lot of things about Xiao Li in order to chase her.
You can ask him questions about dinosaurs, and he knows everything.
Research on the vaccine has already begun.
I can't eat any food related to shrimp because I'm allergic to shrimp.

blocks.html: Finally, to negate 有关 in a formal context, use 无关 (wúguān):

children.english: We will not discuss matters that are not relevant to the theme of this meeting.

一面 (yìmiàn) is more formal than 一边, but is used in the same way to express two simultaneous actions.

blocks.text: 一面 + Verb +  一面 + Verb

children.english: I cried while running away.
He likes to eat and watch movies at the same time.
I've told you so many times: don't eat while lying in bed. You've gotten crumbs all over the bed!
They enjoy the full moon and eat moon cakes together as a family.
Can you pat your head and rub your belly at the same time?
To earn money, my big brother is studying and working part-time at the same time.

blocks.html: 一面 cannot be shortened in the way while 一边 can:

children.english: I work and study at the same time.

blocks.html: 一面 can also be used to express two aspects of a situation, which are not necessarily being enacted simultaneously. This is the same as the structure "一方面……一方面……", or "on the one hand... on the other hand" in English.

children.english: On one hand, the government needs to control inflation, but on the other hand, it needs to guarantee a certain amount of economic growth.

title: Expressing "the more... the more..." with "yue… yue…"

blocks.html: More than "putting stuff" after two instances of 越 (yuè) in a sentence, there are a number of very specific patterns you will notice if you want to get more sophisticated with 越 (yuè) and go beyond using the simpler 越来越 (yuèláiyuè).
It's normally verbs or verb phrases following each 越, but adjectives are also possible (typically after the second 越).

children.english: The more we think about it, the angrier we get.
The more I look at it, the more I like it.

blocks.html: Sometimes this pattern is best translated into English as "more and more," which is similar to 越来越 (yuèláiyuè).

children.explanation: "faster and faster" = "more and more fast"
children.english: He ran faster and faster. / The more he ran, the faster he got.

children.explanation: "heavier and heavier" = "more and more heavy"
children.english: The rain got heavier and heavier. / The more it rained, the heavier it got.

blocks.html: What follows the first 越 is typically the reason why the second 越 phrase happens.
Again, it's normally verbs or verb phrases following each 越, but adjectives are also possible (typically after the second 越).

children.english: The more she talks, the angrier I get.
The more you look at me, the more nervous I am.
The more I walk, the more my legs hurt.

blocks.html: This is actually the same pattern as the last one, but its different English translation makes it worth paying attention to.

children.english: The more you push the kid to study, the less he wants to study.
The more he asks, the less I want to tell him.
The more you talk this way, the less he listens.

blocks.html: This pattern involves the same verb repeated after each 越. It is limited to a small number of single-syllable verbs related to sensory perception, but you do hear it used.

blocks.text: Subj. + 越 + Verb + 越 + 想 + Verb

children.english: The more I read this book, the more I want to keep reading it.

children.explanation: Like Doritos, amirite?
children.english: The more you eat this kind of snack, the more you want to eat it.
I'm always so sleepy after taking this medicine. And also, the more I sleep, the more l want to sleep.

宁可 (nìngkě) is used when the speaker wants to compare two unfavorable options, and choose one over the other. We usually express this as "would rather... than..." in English.
Using 宁可 with 也不
blocks.text: Using 宁可 with 也不

blocks.html: This construction puts 宁可 at the beginning of the sentence followed by 也不. 宁可 is followed by the less unfavorable option and 也不 is followed by the most unfavorable option.

children.english: I'd rather have no boyfriend than find a random one.
We'd rather arrive early than late.
He'd rather lose than give up.
I'd rather spend less money this month than ask my parents for money.
Mom would rather give these things to strangers than throw them away.

blocks.html: Using 宁可 with 也要
blocks.text: Using 宁可 with 也要

blocks.html: In this construction 宁可 is used a little differently. 宁可 is followed by unfavorable actions while 也要 is followed by things that you desire or something that you intend to achieve.
Here the speaker must pay a price in order to complete or gain something, a bit like "even though X, I'm still willing to do Y."

children.english: I'd rather stay up tonight just to finish it.
The kids would rather not eat just to play a little longer.
He would rather break up with his girlfriend just to stay abroad.
She would rather spend half of her salary just to live alone.
I would rather sit in a hard seat for 30 hours if I can get home.

更不用说 (gèng bùyòng shuō) is similar to the English expression "let alone" or "to say nothing of." For example, we might say: "he can't even boil an egg, let alone prepare a banquet."

blocks.text: 连 + A + 都 / 也 + Verb， 更不用说 + B + 了

blocks.html: Notice that the order used in this pattern is the opposite of the 别说 structure.

title: Many types of "not only... but also..."
pattern: 不但 / 不只 / 不仅⋯⋯，而且 / 还 / 也 ⋯⋯

blocks.html: We've seen 不但……而且 (bùdàn... érqiě) at the B1 level, but there are a number of other structures which can be used to express the same thing. 不但 can be substituted with 不仅 (bùjǐn) or 不只 (bùzhǐ), both meaning "not only," and can be followed by 而且 (érqiě), 还 (hái), or 也 (yě). Other than 不但……而且 being more common than the others, they are all similar in usage and formality.
