blocks.html: If something was originally a certain way, or "should be" a certain way, the Chinese words used are often 本来 (běnlái) and 原来 (yuánlái). 本来 (běnlái) is usually an adverb while 原来 (yuánlái) could be either and adjective or an adverb.
本来 + 是 for a Change of Plans
blocks.text: 本来 + 是 for a Change of Plans

blocks.html: If something happened unexpectedly later, 本来 is preferred rather than 原来 considering there is a change of the original situation. 本来 means "originally." Since the action has already happened, the pattern 是⋯⋯的 is suggested here. 是 is optional.

blocks.text: Subj. + 本来 + 是 + [（不）要 / 会 / 应该 ] + Verb + 的，但是 / 可是⋯⋯

children.english: I was originally going to go to your birthday party, but I had to work some extra time this weekend.
He would have done better on the test, but he was sick that day.
We didn't plan to go, but we went in the end because they called us several times.
This work doesn't need to be done by today. But if you want to finish it sooner, you can.
I was originally going to marry him, but then I found that we are just not meant for each other.

blocks.html: 本来 + 就 for Common Sense Statements
blocks.text: 本来 + 就 for Common Sense Statements

blocks.html: 本来 is used when something is common sense. There are certain expectations for the speaker and listener. Since there is no real English equivalent, it is best translated as "it goes without saying." It can also be translated to "supposed to," following it with a certain expectation.

blocks.text: Subj. + 本来 + 就 + 很 / 不 + Adj.
Subj. + 本来 + 就 + [ 会 / 要 / 得 / 应该 ] + Verb

children.english: Life isn't supposed to be very easy.
Moving is supposed to be very troublesome.
Taking care of children is supposed to be the responsibility of parents.
Teachers are supposed to prepare their lessons well.

blocks.html: 本来 + 就 for Emphasis

If you've got an opinion to express after stating how it "should be" or "should not be," then 本来就 will help you sound more convincing. The end of the sentence usually has an imperative or rhetorical question that leads to an opinion or suggestion, emphasizing the tone.

children.english: You are already thin enough and you still want to lose weight?
What he said was wrong all along, so why do you still want me to listen to what he says?
He was never a good person. Why do you still want to help him?
She never liked you in the first place, so stop pursuing her.
The way he talks oten makes people uncomfortable, so don't take it personally.

blocks.html: 原来 + 是 for “It turns out”
blocks.text: 原来 + 是 for “It turns out”

blocks.html: 原来 is more used to emphasize what you accidentally find out or realize in a situation. It's similar to "as it turns out..." or "...all along." For this usage, 原来 is normally located at the beginning of the sentence.

blocks.text: 原来 + 是 + [Fact / Truth / Reason / Purpose]
怪不得 + [Observation / Situation]，原来 + 是 [因为 / 为了 / 想⋯⋯]

children.english: It was you all along! I didn't recognize you until just now.
No wonder your Chinese is so good. You lived in China for more than 30 years.
It turns out that they're living together. No wonder they often come to work and leave work together.
No wonder you treat him so well. You've had feelings for him the whole time.

blocks.html: 原来 + 的 for "Previous" or "Former"

children.english: This is my old house.
His former company closed down.
This is not how you previously thought about it.
My current boyfriend is a lot cuter than my ex.
Your hair was so black before, but now it's become a lot grayer.

Both 才 (cái) and 就 (jiù) are adverbs that have to do with expressing time, and they are both placed before verbs. However, they typically have opposite effects on the tone of the sentence, with 才 (cái) implying a sense of lateness, and 就 (jiù) imparting a sense of earliness.
Emphasis with 才
才 indicates that the speaker feels that the events discussed happened later than expected. Sometimes it also expresses anxiety, impatience, anger, or other related emotions.

children.english: I waited two hours before I could buy the ticket.
The boss didn't come to the office until 11 o'clock.
It's going to take at least two months to complete this project.

blocks.html: Expressing Small Quantity with 才
才 can also mean "only" in the sense of a small quantity.
The key thing to pay attention to here is that the 才 goes before the verb, and not the "small quantity" that follows it.

children.english: We have so many people and you only ordered three dishes.
I bought this many things, and I only spent 500 RMB.

blocks.html: Expressing "Not Late" with 才 and Time
blocks.text: Expressing "Not Late" with 才 and Time

blocks.html: When 才 is followed by a time, it can express the idea of "only," as in, "it's only 9 o'clock," expressing the idea that "9 o'clock is not late." This would seem to be the opposite of the 才 expressing "lateness," but it's important to remember that this 才 precedes a time, and not an action.

children.english: It's only nine o'clock. Stay and hang out a little bit more.
It's only six. Why did you get up so early?

blocks.html: Emphasis with 就
就 indicates that something has occurred earlier than the speaker expected. There may be an accompanying feeling of surprise or amazement.

blocks.text: Subj. + Time + 就 + Verb + Obj.＋了

children.english: She got married when she was only 19.
Your younger sister started college when she was only fifteen?
He ate dinner at four in the afternoon.
You guys getting off work this early?
I left at eight o'clock, but there was a traffic jam, so I was still ten minutes late.

blocks.html: Expressing Small Quantity with 就
就 can be used to mean "only," in the sense of a small quantity.

If you're thinking, "didn't we just learn to use 才 to also mean small quantity??" then you're very perceptive, and the answer is yes. For this "small quantity" emphasis, both 才 and 就 can be used before the verb to express essentially the same thing. (If you really want to split hairs, native speakers might say that there's a tiny difference in emphasis between the two, but that level of nuance goes beyond the scope of this grammar point.)

children.english: We have all these people, and you just bought that one bottle of cola?
Do you only sleep four hours every day?
Everyone wrote five pages, but you wrote just one?
At that time Chinese people all had four or five children, but their family only had one?

blocks.html: Using 才 and 就 Together
blocks.text: Using 才 and 就 Together

blocks.html: They're not matter and anti-matter; these two "opposite" words can actually be used together. When used together, they're the "just recently" meaning of 才 and the "early" meaning of 就. Together, they indicate that one thing just happened recently, and then the other happened soon after.

blocks.text: Subj + 才 + Verb  + 就 + Verb Phrase

children.english: You only just came and you‘re leaving already? Are you not going to sit a little longer?
The movie just started and you don't want to watch it anymore?
He just graduated and already found such a good job?

If something happens frequently, two useful words to describe this concept of "often" in Chinese are 常常 (chángcháng) and 往往 (wǎngwǎng). However, they are used in different ways and different places, so this article will help you distinguish when and where to use them.

常常 simply means something happens frequently and not necessarily regularly, and is also not restricted to a certain precondition. 往往 is used in certain conditions to mean how things can be or are like, sort of like "tend to." It's a conclusion or judgment of a regular situation. 往往 has nothing to do with how often something happens. When using 往往, the sentence itself usually has a kind of condition of an occurring situation or behavior, for example, 商场往往周末的时候比较热闹。This is where 往往 differs from 常常. For the most part, you can translate 常常 as "often," where as you can translate 往往 as "usually." Also, 常常 can omit a 常, but you 往往 cannot omit a 往.

children.english: He often arrives late.
They've been married for almost 30 years. Nevertheless, they fight a lot.
Rich people are usually more superstitious.
Women usually live longer than men.
It's usually more quiet here in Shanghai during Chinese New Year.
Products of good quality usually wouldn't be expensive.

blocks.html: "常常" can be used in an imperative sentence expressing a suggestion. "往往" cannot be used in this kind of situation.

children.english: Do you meet often?
You should exercise more often.
Better not eat spicy food too often. It's not good for your skin.
I can travel more often when I retire.
You need to watch her more often for me when I'm not here.

blocks.html: The difference between the negative and question sentences
blocks.text: The difference between the negative and question sentences

blocks.html: The negated version of "常常" is "不常"，expressing "very rarely." "往往" does not have a negated "不往往," but can appear in negative sentences, mostly expressed as "往往不/没." Also, "常常" can be used in question sentences, but "往往" cannot be.

blocks.text: Subj. + 往往 + 不 / 没 + Verb

children.english: I don't go out for dinner often.
My boss doesn't come to the office often.
We're good friends, but we don't see each other often.
It's usually very hard for rich people to find someone who truly loves them.
Comparatively, private schools are usually expensive.
It's usually not very easy to get a taxi in rainy days.

Both 再 (zài) and 又 (yòu) express the repeating of an action and can be roughly translated in English to "again."  However, 再 is used to express actions that have not yet occurred (the "future again") and 又 is used for actions that have already occurred (the "past again").  They're not interchangeable. In addition, each word has a few special usages.
再 Expresses Repetition of an Action in the Future
blocks.text: 再 Expresses Repetition of an Action in the Future

blocks.html: 再 is used to express something that has already happened and will happen again.

children.english: We will come here again next time.
I want to take another look.

blocks.html: You need to use 再 for this usage; you can't use 又:

children.explanation: Since it is asking about a future action, you can't use "又"

children.english: Please say it one more time.

blocks.html: Aside from expressing the repetition of an action, 再 can also be used to express the equivalent of the English word "another."
Note that the "Object" mentioned above is usually also going to have an 一 and a measure word in front of it. You'll see that in the examples below.

children.english: I want to watch another movie.
Can you make another bowl of noodles?

children.explanation: Since it is about the future, you can't use "又"
children.english: I have to write another essay.

children.explanation: Since it is about the future, you can't use "又"
children.english: I want to eat another piece of cake.

blocks.html: 再 can be used with 先 to express sequential order. (ex. Do this....and then this....) In some cases, 再 can appear by itself to simply mean "and then." While this doesn't sound so easy to confuse with 又, it's actually quite common for intermediate learners to misunderstand this use of 再 as meaning "again," so it's definitely worth mentioning here.

children.english: First we'll do our homework, then we'll go hiking in the mountains.
First I'll buy a house, then I'll get married.
We'll finish eating, then go see a movie.
We can discuss it after we get home, OK?

children.explanation: '"又"can not be used as the action"go to bed" haven't occured yet.
children.english: I want to finish reading the book and then go to sleep.

children.explanation: "又" does not sequence events.
children.english: You should eat before you call your parents.

blocks.html: 又 Expresses Repetition of an Action That Has Already Occurred in the Past
blocks.text: 又 Expresses Repetition of an Action That Has Already Occurred in the Past

blocks.html: 又 is used in declarative sentences and describes the simple repetition of actions. This repeated action has already occurred once in the past.

children.english: Why do you keep calling me? What it it?
This guy is here again.
He didn't come to class again. The teacher is probably going to punish him.
Why are you reading that book again？You've already read it.

children.explanation: "再" is not used for past events.
children.english: He watched TV all day long again yesterday.

children.explanation: "再" is not used for past events.
children.english: I applied for a developer position at Google again yesterday.

blocks.html: 又 Adds Emotional Coloring to Events Recurring in the Future
blocks.text: 又 Adds Emotional Coloring to Events Recurring in the Future

blocks.html: 又 is sometimes used to express that something that has happened before is going to happen in the immediate future. In this case, it usually appears with 要 (yào), 可以 (kěyǐ), 能 (néng), or 是 (shì). This usage often expresses exasperation or impatience with something happening yet again, but sometimes it's more neutral, or even happy.

children.english: Tomorrow is Monday again.
We're having another meeting tomorrow. So annoying!
You're going to resign again? Why?
It's almost summer, and we can eat ice cream again!
If I can slim down a bit, I can wear my favorite jeans again!

blocks.text: Both 再 and 又 Have Other Uses as Well

blocks.html: Adverbs is 总算 (zǒngsuàn) and 终于 (zhōngyú) both can be translated as "finally" or "in the end," but they subtly different in tone.

Grammatically, 总算 and 终于 are used basically the same way. They are both adverbs, and they can be placed before the subject or after the subject. However, in comparison to 终于, 总算 is seldom used before the subject. In the simple sentences given below, however, they are fully interchangeable.

blocks.text: Subj. + 总算 / 终于 + Verb

children.english: You finally came!
I finally understood it.
The rain finally stopped.
I finally found you!
The plane is finally taking off!

blocks.html: 总算 is More Informal and Impatient
blocks.text: 总算 is More Informal and Impatient

blocks.html: Both 总算 and 终于 express that an action has finally happened after a long wait, however 总算 implies that the speaker had a bit of an agonizing wait, and it has a heavier tone better suited to complaints.

children.english: Thank God, you finally came.
You finally didn't arrive late.
She finally got over her cold.

blocks.html: 终于 is more formal and objective
blocks.text: 终于 is more formal and objective

blocks.html: 终于 is more formal than 总算 (in other words, 总算 is more for spoken Chinese), and it also has a more objective feel (meaning that the speaker isn't just being impatient and there was indeed a very long wait for this thing that finally happened).

children.english: You finally decided!
You're finally going on vacation. You're happy about it, aren't you?
This project you've been working on together has finally succeeded!

跟 (gēn) and 对 (duì) sometimes seem like they mean the same thing, and at other times they seem to be different. You need to be aware which cases are which.
Used with 说 in the Same Way
blocks.text: Used with 说 in the Same Way

blocks.html: When using the verb 说, 跟 and 对 can both be used in a similar sentence pattern. 跟 and 对 are both prepositions, and they both express one person speaking to another.

blocks.text: Person A + 跟 / 对 + Person B 说

children.english: I told her, but she didn't believe me.
I told her, but she didn't believe me.
He told me he loved me.
He told me he loved me.
What did you just tell him?
What did you just tell him?

blocks.html: 跟 and 对 can both be verbs, and they are often used with 着, however their meanings are different.
Examples for 跟
跟 can be a verb, and its simplest meaning is "follow." Often it is used as a verb phrase, such as 跟着, 跟上, 跟不上, or 跟得上.

children.english: This little cat always follows me.
You walk too fast, I can't keep up.

blocks.html: Examples for 对
对 is also a verb, put it has the meaning of "towards" or "point to." Often it is used as: 对着, 对上, 对不上.

children.english: Don't point guns at people.
I like to laugh at myself in the mirror.
These two accounts don't match up.

blocks.html: When to Use 跟 and Not 对
blocks.text: When to Use 跟 and Not 对

blocks.html: 跟 is a preposition, and it can be used in comparison patterns. 对 cannot be used this way.
Comparison Structure with 一样
This structure is used to explain that two things are (or aren't) similar.

children.english: I am not like you guys. I still have kids.
Shanghai and New York are alike; they are both international cities.

blocks.html: Comparison Structure with 一样 + Adj.
blocks.text: Comparison Structure with 一样 + Adj.

blocks.html: This structure shows that two nouns are the same in some some aspect, which is the word that follows "一样."

blocks.text: A + 跟 + B + （不）一样 + Adj.

children.english: Now I'm as tall as my dad.
You like to buy clothes just like your mother.

blocks.html: 跟 functions as a conjunction in this structure, joining two things together. Generally, these are nouns or pronouns (as with 和). 对 cannot function like this.

children.english: Are you going to go with me?
Flowers and chocolate are the best gifts.

blocks.html: When to Use 对 and not 跟
blocks.text: When to Use 对 and not 跟

blocks.html: When 对 as a preposition, it points to a certain target, since it can mean "facing" or "toward." 跟 can only be used this way with 说.

children.english: That pretty girl is laughing at me.
Don't lose your temper with the boss, otherwise there will be serious consequences.

title: Comparing "chao" "xiang" and "wang"
pattern: 朝 vs 向 vs 往

blocks.html: All three of these, 朝 (cháo), 向 (xiàng), and 往 (wǎng) can be used to indicate direction or position. When these preposition phrases are used before a verb, the three have the same structure and their meaning is the same. Although they are often interchangeable, there are also cases when they are not.
When 朝, 向, and 往 Are All Appropriate
blocks.text: When 朝, 向, and 往 Are All Appropriate

blocks.html: Just put one of the three before the direction and the verb!

blocks.text: 向 / 朝 / 往 + Direction + Verb

blocks.html: The three are interchangeable in these types of "purely directional" usage.

children.english: From here, go one hundred meters north, and you'll get there.
This little girl looked left and then looked right before crossing the street.
I saw him going towards your house.
Walk forward for ten minutes.

blocks.html: When to Use 向 and 往
blocks.text: When to Use 向 and 往

blocks.html: 向 and 往 can sometimes be placed after a verb, however not just any verb will do. Oft-used verbs are 开, 飞, 发, 运, 送, 寄, 带, 驶 etc. As you can see, these are words that imply some sort of motion. In addition, compared to 向, 往 is used more often with those verbs, because 往 indicates the destination while 向 merely expresses a direction,. 朝 is not used this way.

children.english: This train is heading towards Shenyang.
This plane is bound for New York.
A small black sedan slowly drove from east to west.
Like a bird, it flew into the blue yonder.

blocks.html: When to Use "向" and "朝"
When a concrete action has a specific target (not a destination), use 向 or 朝. 往 cannot be used this way.

blocks.text: 向 / 朝 + Target + Concrete Verb

children.english: He chuckled at me.
I took a shot at him.
He has already explained it to all the employees.

blocks.html: When a verb and or the target of the verb is abstract, you can only use 向 to indicate the target, and cannot use 朝.

children.english: He is an exemplary employee, we should all learn from him.
We are going to demand that the Environmental Safety Department closely inspect the factory's sewage.
Is this subway heading towards Pudong Airport?
You need to go to him to learn.
When the handsome guy headed my way I smiled.
When the handsome guy headed my way I smiled.
The cute guy smiled at me.
He walked south.
Idiot! Why did you let him go south? Going south is dangerous!
Why are you getting mad at me? I told him but he didn't listen
I'm sorry. I should apologize to you.

对 (duì) and 对于 (duìyú) can be confusing because they overlap quite a bit in usage, but they are not entirely interchangeable.
对 and 对于 Are Equivalent When Used as Prepositions
blocks.text: 对 and 对于 Are Equivalent When Used as Prepositions

blocks.html: When 对 and 对于 are used as prepositions to modify a verb, they are basically the same. As a matter of fact, when used this way 对 is just the simplification of 对于! 对于 sounds a bit more formal.
In the following example sentences, 对 and 对于 are interchangeable.

children.english: As for this kind of thing, what's your perspective?
I've never liked or disliked Shanghai.

blocks.html: 对 Is More Versatile within a Sentence
blocks.text: 对 Is More Versatile within a Sentence

blocks.html: Both 对 and 对于 can be placed before or after the subject in a sentence. Unlike 对, however, 对于 cannot be placed after the adverb in the middle of a sentence.
They can both go in the very front:
They can both go right after the subject:
Only one can go right before the predicate:
All of the above examples mean "we are all interested in this problem."
对 Can Be Used as a Verb
blocks.text: 对 Can Be Used as a Verb

blocks.html: As a Verb Meaning "to face"
When 对 is used as a verb, it expresses "to face" or "to point at," and you will often see it in the form 对着. It can also be used in verb phrases which refer to "matching," like 对上 and 对不上.

blocks.text: Subj. + 对着 ／ 对上 ／ 对不上

children.english: Don't point the gun at people.
I like to laugh at the mirror.
Did the two numbers match up?
These two accounts don't match up.

blocks.html: 对 Can Be Used with Emotional Adjectives
blocks.text: 对 Can Be Used with Emotional Adjectives

blocks.html: To indicate to whom an emotional response is directed, you can use 对 but not 对于.

children.english: He treats his work very seriously.
My boyfriend is very good to me.
We are all very suspicious of this guy.
He's very serious about his work.
What do you think about this?
I understand her completely. She can't do it like this.

title: Comparing "duiyu" and "zhiyu"
pattern: 关于 vs 对于 vs 至于

blocks.html: The differences between 对于 (duìyú) and 至于 (zhìyú) can be confusing. They both have similar meanings like "concerning," "regarding" or "as for," and differences are subtle.
Use 对于 to Emphasizes the Object
blocks.text: Use 对于 to Emphasizes the Object

blocks.html: 对于 usually emphasizes the thing that it is pointing to. Usually where you use 对 you can also use 对于.
As an adverb or adverbial clause, you can place 对于 before or after the subject. It cannot be an attributive modifier (coming before a noun).

children.english: With regards to computers, I don't understand anything.
I don't understand anything about computers.
With this kind of person, you shouldn't try to reason with them.

blocks.html: Use 至于 to Change the Topic
blocks.text: Use 至于 to Change the Topic

blocks.html: Note that to change a topic, there needs to be another topic first. So you don't use 至于 to start an entirely new discussion free of any existing topic.
As a preposition, 至于 points to another topic, serving to change the subject of conversation.

children.english: We're going to start this project, but as for when to start, we still haven't decided.
As for this issue, we still need further discussion.

blocks.html: Use 至于 to Emphasize Degree
blocks.text: Use 至于 to Emphasize Degree

blocks.html: As an adverb, it expresses "having reached a certain degree." After it you can add words or phrases that describe degree. You can also say 至于 by itself or use 不至于.

children.english: Over such a small thing, why are you so angry?
I'm not happy, but not to the point that I won't talk with you.

children.explanation: Questioning someone's overreaction, perhaps
children.english: Is it that serious?
Regarding this issue, what do you think?
Are you not to happy about his rude behavior?

Both 给 and 为 can mean "for." They seem to be arbitrarily assigned to different verbs, and to make matters worse, some verbs (but not all!) can use either one. There are a few principles you can use to keep them straight, but also a few exceptions you need to memorize. As always, lots of examples help!
The Core Meaning of 给

As you know, 给 is also a verb meaning "to give." As such, 给 is often used with verbs to express an action done out of kindness or friendship. Think of all the things a mother does for a child, or a generous friend does for her bestie. These would use 给.

children.english: Please get me a pair of chopsticks.
After getting off the plane, I'll give you a call.
Don't forget to reply to my email.
My coworker explained the company's situation to me.
What you did was wrong. Apologize to him.
The boss gave me a lot of suggestions.
Shanghai left a deep impression on me.

blocks.html: The Core Meaning of 为

The word 为 automatically feels more formal than 给, due to its association with classical Chinese. Besides being more formal, it is also often associated with obligatory actions or responsibilities. The typical example of this is "to work for Company A": 为A公司工作.

One other common usage of 为 is for uncontrollable emotional reactions that result from relationships with other people. These reactions aren't really done out of kindness; they're spontaneous and not a result of a conscious choice.

children.english: I currently work for Google.
Have you made a contribution to our country?
I'm truly happy for you.
The parents did a lot for their child.
When parents micro-manage their kids, they always say it's for their children's own good.
We've all adults now, and ought to be responsible for our own actions.
The government provides companies certain protections.

关于 (guānyú) and 对于 (duìyú) seem similar, since both of these prepositions are used to point to specific people or things. However, when taking a closer look, the things they discuss and the angles they take are different.
Examples with 对于
对于 points to an object being specifically referred to, and usually the speaker has adopted a certain attitude or has come to some kind of conclusion about the person or object.

children.english: As for that person, I just don't know him very well at all.
The boss is very satisfied with our work performance.
He doesn't really have any opinion about this matter.

blocks.html: Examples with 关于
关于 names a topic, and often emphasizes a range, then introduces a comment related to it.

children.english: Yesterday he made a speech about the Chinese economy.
I need to write an article about the differences between Chinese and American culture.
With regards to your application for resignation, the company is still considering it.
On children's education, her opinion is very different from her husband's.

blocks.html: Using 关于 in a Formal Way
blocks.text: Using 关于 in a Formal Way

blocks.html: 关于 (guānyú) can also be used in the title of an article.

children.english: "Regarding Department Adjustments and Human Affairs"
A Notification Regarding New Year Holidays

blocks.html: Situations Where 关于 and 对于 Are Interchangeable
blocks.text: Situations Where 关于 and 对于 Are Interchangeable

blocks.html: When the point emphasized is pretty clear (whether it be a range or a specific thing), then you can use either.

children.english: Is there anything that anyone wants to add to this decision?
As for this issue, what other thoughts do you all have?
The content of today's meeting is a discussion about the problems in developing China's markets.
My opinion towards the Chinese markets is that we still don't understand. The best thing is to wait a bit longer.
We've already decided about developing the markets, the issue now is when to start.
Then, as for this topic, I have nothing more to say.

Mixing up the order of the two syllables in a word is something most learners do. This makes the pair 适合 (shìhé) and 合适 (héshì) annoying, to say the least. They mean more or less the same thing, but the former is a verb, while the latter is an adjective.
The Verb 适合
适合 is a verb meaning "to suit," and should take an object.

children.english: This job really suits me.
Your Chinese name suits you well.

children.explanation: This translation is a little awkward in English, but we're trying to avoid using the word "suitable," which is an adjective.
children.english: This movie does not suit children (to watch).

blocks.html: The Adjective 合适
合适 is an adjective meaning "suitable" or "appropriate," and is used in the same way as other adjectives.

children.english: Inside the office, it's not really appropriate to smoke, right?
He is just the most suitable. He totally fulfills our hiring requirements.
Although iPads are fun to use, the price is not so suitable for me.

blocks.html: Don't Confuse the Two

children.explanation: This would be treating 合适 like a verb
适合 is a verb!
children.english: This suits me.

children.explanation: This would be treating 适合 like an adjective
合适 is an adjective!
children.english: This shoe size fits you well.

children.speaker: A
children.english: Do you know what kind of clothes would be appropriate for this party?

children.speaker: B
children.english: I don't know, but wearing jeans is definitely not appropriate.

平时 (píngshí) and 平常 (píngcháng) look very similar (after all, they do start with 平), and they have similar meanings of "often" or "usually," but they have slightly different uses.
Both 平时 and 平常 Are Used as Adverbs
blocks.text: Both 平时 and 平常 Are Used as Adverbs

blocks.html: Both 平时 and 平常 can be used as adverbs. They are interchangeable in this case.

children.english: Do you often work out?
I usually don't eat snacks.
Do you usually watch the news?
She usually doesn't buy luxury goods.

blocks.html: 平常 as an Adjective
When 平常 is used as an adjective, it expresses the meaning of "common." 平时 cannot be used this way.

children.english: The work of sanitary workers is very ordinary, but it is also very important.
This kind of thing is very common.
For China, 2008 was not an ordinary year.
In China, is it common to go to a bar for entertainment?

children.speaker: A
children.english: What do you usually cook?

children.speaker: B
children.english: They're all just ordinary dishes.

Both "以后" (yǐhòu) or "之后" (zhīhòu) mean "after," but there are a few tiny differences in usage.
Similarities between 以后 and 之后
blocks.text: Similarities between 以后 and 之后

blocks.html: Both can indicate another event happened after a specific time.

blocks.text: Subj. + Specified Time + 以后／之后 + Verb

blocks.html: In situations something happens after something else, you can use 以后. The stipulation with this is that "after WHAT" needs to be explicitly stated. That is, there has to be a "specified time" for 以后 to modify. Otherwise 以后 won't work in those sentences.
以后 and 之后 may be freely interchanged in any of the below sentences.

children.english: After it rains, the air will be a lot better.
After getting married, they had two babies.
After I get a raise, I will treat take you out to eat.
After I heard this news, I was so happy I couldn't sleep the whole night.

blocks.html: Differences between 以后 and 之后
blocks.text: Differences between 以后 and 之后

blocks.html: The key to understanding 以后 here is that if it doesn't come immediately after something else, then it's being used by itself. And when 以后 is used by itself, it doesn't mean "after;" it means "in the future."
以后 by Itself Means "In the Future"
blocks.text: 以后 by Itself Means "In the Future"

children.english: In the future I will never come to this place to eat again. It's expensive and the food is terrible.
In the future I might go to college abroad.
We'll talk about future issues in the future.

blocks.html: 之后 by Itself Means "After that"
blocks.text: 之后 by Itself Means "After that"

blocks.html: Compared to 以后, 之后 is a little more flexible. Not only can it be used just like 以后, modifying the time, but it can also appear independently, meaning something along the lines of "after that." While 以后 must come after a specific time to mean "after," it cannot can stand by itself like this.

children.english: I'm going to go home and drop my stuff off first, after that go to the cafe to look for you.
Last summer, he came to my house. After that, I haven't seen him.

blocks.html: Common Mistakes with 以后 and 之后
blocks.text: Common Mistakes with 以后 and 之后

blocks.html: In the following sentences, 以后 is not grammatical when it's not directly coupled with a time or event telling you after what. 之后 can be used here to mean "after that."

children.english: I will get off work at six o'clock. After that, I will meet a friend for dinner.

children.explanation: When a time is specified, both are fine.
children.english: Yesterday after finishing eating with my friends, we played basketball.
Yesterday I ate dinner with a friend. Afterward, we went to a pet shop.

pattern: 以后 vs. 然后 vs. 后来

blocks.html: While both 以后 (yǐhòu) and 后来 (hòulái) can mean "later," they have distinct uses. 然后 (ránhòu) means "and then." Don't let yet another 后 word confuse you!
然后 is a conjunction, which is always used in the middle of a sequence of events. It is often used with 先 (xiān, meaning "first"). Neither 以后 nor 后来 can be used this way.

children.english: Let's do some review first and then study a new lesson.
Let's do some review first and then study a new lesson.
My plan is to stay at my friend's friend, and then find a place to live.
We're going to Beijing on a business trip, and after that we'll go to Europe on vacation.

blocks.html: Simply swapping 以后 for 然后 in each of these sentences would make them correct.
然后 without 先

children.english: We'll meet downstairs and then we go together.
The baby woke up. He cried for a little while and then fell asleep again.
China is the biggest developing country and then it's India.

blocks.html: Usage of 以后
以后 as "In the Future"
以后 is a time noun, which can be used to talk about things that happen at some unspecified point in the future while 然后 and 后来 can't be used this way.

children.english: I want to start up my own business in the future.
Please stop coming here in the future.

blocks.html: 以后 as "After"
Note that the time can be specific (like a date or time) or broad (like an event, action, or occurrence).

children.english: I will come back in an hour.
He went abroad after he graduated.

blocks.html: 后来 is used to sequence two events that have already occurred. It is the Chinese equivalent of the English word "afterward."

children.english: He worked for our company for two years, and then he jumped ship.
Afterwards he moved to the US. And then his parents also moved over there.

children.speaker: A
children.english: I'll go to your house first, then we can go together to see her.

children.speaker: B
children.english: Sure. I haven't seen her in so long! Have you seen each other since she went abroad?

children.speaker: A
children.english: We met once, but I haven't seen her since then.

blocks.html: Both 看起来 (kànqilai) and 看来 (kànlái) are related to how something "looks," but they are used in different ways. Whereas 看起来 indicates an appraisal of a physical situation, 看来 expresses a user's understanding of a situation.
看起来 Describes a Physical Appearance
blocks.text: 看起来 Describes a Physical Appearance

blocks.html: 看起来 is used to describe physical appearances. In other words, one can use 看起来 to literally describe what something "looks like."

children.english: Our daughter looks really happy today.
This dish looks really tasty.
These two pieces of clothing look pretty much the same.
The boss has been too busy lately. He looks really tired.

blocks.html: 看起来 + 像 for Direct Visual Comparisons
blocks.text: 看起来 + 像 for Direct Visual Comparisons

blocks.html: 看起来 can also be used to express how something "looks like" something else. But unlike the previous usage of 看起来, and with the help of 像, we can explicitly state what the object looks like.

children.english: Your big sister is so pretty! She looks like a celebrity.
This whole thing looks like it's meant to scam people.
They don't look like good people.
Does he look like that friend of mine?

blocks.html: 看来 When Assessing a Situation
blocks.text: 看来 When Assessing a Situation

blocks.html: 看来 can be used to express one's interpretation of a situation. Note that when 看来 is used in a manner, the speaker isn't usually commenting on the visual or physical appearance of anything. Rather, 看来 indicates the speaker's perspective or conclusion about how a situation "looks."

children.english: It's raining so hard. It seems he's not coming.
There aren't many people at this restaurant. It seems the food isn't so good.
It seems now that he's just not that into you.

blocks.html: 看来 as "From X's Perspective"

看来 can also be used to make a subjective statement from a particular person's perspective. A more literal translation would be "the way [Person] sees it...." This full form is more common in formal writing and speaking.

children.english: The way I see it, the best solution is for everyone to cooperate.
From his perspective, this is a very simple matter.

Both 显得 (xiǎnde) and 看起来 (kànqǐlái) have meanings in English like "to appear to be" or "seems like," but their connotations are subtly different.
显得 is used for objective descriptions and comparisons. Use it when you want to say that something "appears" a certain way without emphasizing that it's just your own viewpoint.

children.english: Dressing like this makes me appear more mature.
Eating like that makes you look very impolite.
Doing this makes you appear stingy.
Saying that made her appear stupid.
This color of clothing doesn't go well with your complexion.

blocks.html: 看起来 Emphasizes Subjectivity
看起来 is the opposite of 显得 in that it emphasizes subjectivity, emphasizing how the observer feels.

children.english: You seem very happy today.
This restaurant seems pretty good. Let's try it out.
She seems a little angry.
Your clothes look quote expensive.
Your girlfriend looks like my Chinese teacher.

children.speaker: A
children.english: You look very slim today.

children.speaker: B
children.english: It's probably these clothes that makes me appear that way.
